reviewText:
This game is honestly very good.  You're easily getting a game worth more than the $5 you're paying for it.

What I like about this game is being able to individually control all of your people, giving them jobs, equipping them, etc..  Your man power actually matters in this game instead of them feeling like dead weight like they did in State of Decay.  In SoD you pretty much had to do everything yourself as the player.  In this game, you actually have to delegate orders to ALL of your community members unless you want to run back and forth hauling boards and chicken wire a few at a time.  Your community actually feels like, a, well, community.  It's not unlike in SoD where you radio in for someone to come grab stuff while being arbitrarily limited by the game.  It's the same principle, but a very different execution.  Whereas SoD focuses more on exploration and beating up zombies, Survivalist focuses more on the town building.

You get this game for the awesome town and community building aspect.  If you want to run around slaughtering zombies, there are better alternatives, like State of Decay, because that is not the object of this game.

reviewText:
This game is GREAT! I have no idea why Steam keep pushing Early Access scams on my front page, when there are brilliant games like this already available. I had never heard of it. I also always wanted to play a Action-RPG/RTS Hybrid with Base Building... this scratched the itch with its zombified claws.
--
INTRODUCING you to Survivalist. One of the few Indie titles that really lives up to its screenshots and descriptions, this can easily get you hooked for hours.
Play as you like: be the careless, selfish, evil badass people like to think you are, be the paragon savior of the land, or decide for yourself who deserves to keep breathing in a world where trust is the best currency.
Do you seek Money, Power or Love?

GRAPHICS and AUDIO are good and more than enough for what the game was trying to accomplish.

CONTROLS are simple: WASD to move, right-click to aim and swipe mouse horizontally or vertically to change target or change aim (legs/body/head), left-click to fire/use/select, mouse-wheel to select dialogue options.
Pressing Control will enable Command Mode, in which you can give orders or assign job (or roles) to your characters.
You can also press F to pause, or G to Fast-Forward up to 4x speed.
From F1 to F4 you can select the menus (Inventory/Community/Quests/Map screens). Therefore, no need for crazy hand-dancing when equipping your 5 new recruits!

COMBAT is also simple and straightforward.
Almost all ZOMBIES are fast-moving, and there are different zombies strains, which means each strain is stronger than the other. You'd be smart to adapt yourself and your squad when fighting weaker enemies to preserve ammo, or stronger enemies to prevent instant deaths if bitten. Also, remember to bring some antigen (antidote") and bandages!
Against LOOTERS (or human opponents in general)

reviewText:
The game offers pretty much all it advertised, something I thought rather rare for a 5 € game.

You're pretty much thrown into the post-apocalyptic world unawares, unequipped, climbing out of your Vault (where have I seen this before?) and completely unprepared for the horrors outside. Thankfully, the game's first tutorial run provides an easy crash course into the game world and mechanics, first strolling you thru combat, party interactions, building bases and trading and so forth.

You'll soon be on your way to building your own post-apo settlement to your own whims, within certain limitations. In addition to your zombie neighbours (colour-coded for your convenience), you'll be setting up diplomatic relations with other settlements in the neighbourhood, with various shantytown or lone survivors out in the boons.

What I did like about the game world was the surprising outcomes and twists in quests- instead of plain boring fetch quests, you can sometimes blunder right into a moral dilemma that needs to be solved on the spot, usually either resulting in placating hostiles, or turning previously friendly forces into hostiles, or score some extra loot or survivors for your settlement.

So, I was somewhat pleasantly surprised when I was tasked with 'wiping out Looters' (the staple of the post-apocalyptic quest world), and instead of brutally gunning everybody down, I was given the choice of sparing a survivor of the group, recruiting them for my cause, instead of persisting in the silly tradition of game foes have of fighting to the death, even against unwinnable odds.

Another time, I was sent to kill looters who stole food from a settlement- only to find out the truth to the matter was not all black and white, as the quest giver had originally let on.

Overall, the game is no State of Decay, Dead State, Rebuild: Gangs of Deadsville or Project Zomboid, but it has it's moments- the combat mechanics tend to be very twitchy, with split seconds to open fire on the Infected, as they barrel down on you from the desert with a hankering for survivor flesh. The infection mechanic is pretty simple- you get bit, you gotta get an antidote. Different strains of the disease have different germination times, with the worse strains taking down the host in minutes, requiring survivors to have the proper antidote at hand, or succumb to the disease themselves. Ammo is usually pretty abundant, and you even score 10.000 pistol rounds in the first hour of the game, so you are unlikely to run out of ammo for the basic shooter during your first days. By day 5, I had enough ammo to spare, equipping most of my resource mules with shotguns, my main character with a automatic rifle and farmers and builders with pistols.

Instead of bottlecaps, food and water, your main currency in the wasteland is gold, which is surprisingly abundant in spite of the whole apocalyptic scenario. I found this somewhat funny that while the game makes it clear that paper money is worthless, the concept that the new economy would be based on a non-essential luxury item is kind of a strange notion. Still, it's no a big deal- you'll end up doing more barter than plain gold trading most of the time, anyway.

So, to summarize:

PROS:

+ Freebuild of your own settlement, within some limitations
+ Additional diplomacy and unexpected realism with some sidequests, moral dilemmas
+ Game's difficult, but does not punish you horribly
+ You can delegate resource fetching, farming, building
+ Survivor AI is not completely helpless if left to their own devices. Pathfinding is decent.

CONS:

- The minimap and survivor topdown view are much too close, even on 1920x1080 resolution, giving the game a 640-x480 look.
- Sometimes survivor messages on the right zoom past at astounding speeds, and you miss whatever tooltip or notice was in question.
- Your survivors are practically blind, barely able to see ten feet in any given direction, so they'll constantly get bushwhacked by super-fast, feral zombies until the route is cleared with buckshot, which brings me to...
- Fast undead. Combat is arcade-y, twitchy, sometimes almost Press 'X' not to die.
- Survivor animations on walk and run are a bit wonky.
- Molotov aiming is a game of chance.
- Some of the music tracks are really tiring. Others, not so bad.

Still, for five bucks, this game is not a bad investment, and probably a good diversion to anyone else who enjoys zombies and town management mixes.

reviewText:
The game has all the content to be a great survival game - scavenging, base constructing, farming, item crafting, diplomacy, trading... unfortunately it suffers from a terrible lack of balance that completely breaks realism.

First, the zombies aren't actually 'fast zombies', they are 'olympic runner zombies'. They will charge you from beyond your seeing distance at the speed of a cheetah and then lunge at you from 3 meters away to tackle you. Combat is just 'dodge - shoot - dodge - shoot' until your enemies are dead. There's no room for strategy/tactics or even a little bit of thinking. It isn't difficult, but it lacks depth and quickly becomes uninteresting. And in case you're wondering, there's no stealth mechanic so zombies always aggro you before you can see them, no way around this.

The shooting mechanics are also frustrating - guns are very inaccurate even at close range. The characters could miss the side of a barn at 10 feet, literally. And since zombies have quite a bit of health, you'll empty a few clips to kill them. If you wait without moving long enough, you can make a perfectly accurate shot but this rarely happens since you're fighting marathon runner zombies. The time it takes to aim a perfect shot at 3 feet is way too long anyway to be realistic.

Then there's ammo - there's too much of it lying around to be realistic or to feel like you're struggling to scavenge for supplies. Out of bullets? Just search the nearest house or car and I guarantee you'll find enough to kill a few zombies. Yes, since guns are so inaccurate it's a good thing there's lots of ammo, but why not just make guns more accurate and give the player less ammo? At least it would feel realistic and like you're actually in a post-apocalyptic world were supplies are scarce. Right now it feels like the entire US Air Force airdropped all their ammo reserves over the game map.

Next problem is the inventory size. Characters can't carry a lot of stuff without backpacks so scavenging runs are very unproductive. The ammo you need to carry with you also takes up a lot of inventory room even if you just carry enough at once to kill 5 zombies. This isn't a problem when you have backpacks, but it can take time to find them. And by the way, you NEED a backpack if you want a character to do any construction. Construction requires you to carry a heavy toolbox + construction materials, you can't just drop the materials at the construction site and then come back with the tools to complete the job. Without a backpack, most characters don't have enough inventory room to build anything. That means when you leave someone at base to build stuff, that's one less backpack you can give your guys going out to find supplies. It also means the first backpack you find won't help you scavenge because building barricades will be more important at that point, so you'll have to keep looking for another one if you want your scavenging runs to actually become productive.

Then there's the time lapse. The days just go by too fast. Your characters have to regularly eat, drink, sleep and some have medical conditions that require taking meds like diabetes/insulin. So whenever I speak to an NPC, I feel like I'm wasting precious time. Seriously, a 2 minute conversation feels like a terrible, unproductive waste of time. I never ask NPCs about their backstory, I only use dialogue for quests or trading. And when I speak to an NPC, I just quickly fly over the dialogue.

And with time flying by so fast, well you need to get food and meds quickly. Your characters will eat them up almost faster than you can get them, especially the meds. Just like with combat, there's no time to think or plan, you have to keep moving.

This isn't a survival game, it's a fast-paced arcade game with survival elements. And it's a shame, because it could be an awesome survival game just by modifying a few variables.

Sure, it's only five bucks. But then again, it's a game I quickly gave up playing with no intention of playing it again. It's a game I want to enjoy, but it needs modifications to be an actual survival game and less of an arcade game. Right now it feels like the devs just had no idea how to balance difficulty properly in a game, so they made zombies sprint, they made your guns less accurate than a nerf gun, and then they gave you thousands of ammo lying around everywhere to make sure you wouldn't run out.

Would sure be nice if they fixed this or at least provided a minimum of mod support. It's just stupid how close this came to being a really great game in it's genre, yet failed completely.

reviewText:
This isn't so much a review as a letter of appreciation for the developer. I feel guilty I only paid $5 dollars for this game. If you decide to crowd-fund your next game, please make note of it on your blog so people can donate.  I have gotten an immense amount of fun out of Survivalist, far beyond its actual retail price.

I've tried to figure out why this game was so addictive for me, and I think it comes down to a combination of the post-apocalyptic setting, the crafting and community building element, the exploration system, and the strategy and foresight required to reach the end of the game. If these elements appeal to you individually, the combination of them will bring you many days of fun.

There were bad times though. The first few hours, I derisively referred to this game as Insulin Quest.  Watching my team split up and run off in four different directions because I was walking to close to a the edge of a cliff was a serious, recurring frustration. I became more afraid of slight elevations than I was of White Strain infected. I also did not like that human-on-human violence played such a big, hard-wired role in the game.

But nonetheless I couldn't put the game down until I had beaten it and replayed it, and I can't recommend it enough to anyone who appreciates those good qualities I have described.

reviewText: Survivalist Review\nWhen I was first asked to do a review for Survivalist, I admit that my expectations were a bit low due to the old-school graphics and the relatively low price on an indie game developed and published by a single individual I hadn't heard of before. Being a veteran of survival, RPG, and all types of strategy games in general I still intended to give a fair review based on the game's content. Twenty minutes into the game all i could say was Wow!" This game is amazing and so much fun. It masterfully mixes Survival
hoursPlayed:
and Action elements into a highly addictive adventure that will entertain you for numerous hours and even at full price I strongly recommend this game to fans of all these genres. Not convinced? Then read on...

In Survivalist the ultimate goal is obviously to survive yet another zombie apocalypse. Except that these zombies offer a greater challenge than typical survival games. The infection has multiple strains with varying effects and incubational periods before turning into a zombie yourself. Each will require an antigen specific for that particular type. Another difference is that these zombies are incredibly fast and agile. Don't expect to outrun them. In this game its fight or die.

Surviving will ultimately depend on building a strong community of people working together. You will need to build a strong base able to defend against attacks. It will also need to provide other basic basic needs to survivors like clean drinking water
voteText: fresh crops of food

votesFunny: perform tasks
commentsCount: or even strong-arm characters into joining. There are countless possibilites based on dialogue and other decisions made over the course of the game. Its really nice how all choices have consequences. And
column16:
don't be fooled. Not everybody you encounter is a friendly face ready to welcome you with open arms. There are other survivor communities and bands of looters scattered across the map with their own needs in mind.

Members of your community can be assigned to perform different jobs either by direct control or by using the command feature which will enable you to avoid the hassles of micromanagement. Individuals have a handful of stats that level up through use of that particular skill. They are affected by respect and approval ratings even after being recruited so they can decide to leave your community if they become unhappy with your leadership skills. These are just some of the many challenges that this game offers.

The Good:
=======+  Solid story and quality content
+  Numerous options and variety of choices
+  Entirely sandbox and open (aside from the tutorial)
+  UI is easy to use
+  Good quality graphics
+  Sound quality
+  Rotating camera
+  Full controller support
+  High replay value
+  Realistic concepts
+  Variable speed settings
+  Stability (lack of bugs and crashes)
+  Low requirements/runs well on older machines
+  Steam Achievements
+  Developer friendly and active in community

The Bad:
======-  No option to turn tutorial hints off
-  No ambient sounds in background
-  No useful vehicles or items for transporting resources
-  Crafting is minimal (somewhat abandoned concept?)
-  Could be multiplayer or co-op?

Final Thoughts:
===========Survivalist is definitely one of those games Steam users won't want to miss. I strongly recommend picking this game up if you're a fan of Survival

reviewText:
This game costs only £4, but it contains hours of fun for those who want to enjoy a zombie apocolypse game where you build your own community.

I adore this game. The choices you make can define how your gameplay is, such as: Should I recruit this group of five to my community? They could be used for guarding, farming or constructing buildings, but they also need to be fed which can drain my supplies and risk my other survivors' lives if they venture out to get more food for them.

I am very impressed by this game, considering that it costs such a small price is a big surprise for the quality of it. I wish we could see more games like these more and State of Decay. I adore a game where you build a community during an apocolypse or other circumstances.

The only cons I would say about this game is that the camera angle and this 'fog of war' that limits your visibility to such a small sight, by the time you've seen a group of infected and raised your gun, they're already on top of you and infecting you. I have had this happen quite often, which is an annoyance. The other con would be the unecessarily fast zombies in this game, there is nothing that has annoyed me more than having one of my runners ambushed by a group of infected and then constantly caught by them when they try to outrun them, eventually they either get caught and bitten due to the poor fatigue that takes a long time to improve or they waste all their ammo on shooting them whilst moving, which is irritating due to the poor accuracy when moving even when a survivor is right in front of them.

Overall, there are improvements to be made, but this game at the current moment is great in my opinion.

reviewText:
TL;DR: A surprisingly deep, yet inexpensive, game that covers a lot of ground left undisturbed by many titles in the survival genre. I highly recommend it!

Survivalist has a lot of things going against it, to be honest. It's one of a plethora of titles in the survival genre, it employs a very basic graphics package, and it's developed by a relatively small shop, just to name a few. That said, in my opinion it far surpasses so many of its peers in so many ways. Here's my short list of exactly how it does it:
- Choices matter. Virtually everything you do has consequences, including your interactions with the environment, your community (i.e. the survivors who join you) and NPCs. These consequences do have some remedies, but they take work to get around.
- There's a lot of quests/missions. In my playthrough, almost nothing has to be done in a particular sequence, in that you can put things on hold if you like and do your own sandbox thing for a while.
- Strategy AND tactics. You can choose the RTS controls for some overarching activity, and then take control of a particular character to make sure something is done the way you want it. Perfect for your micromanaging streak while allowing you accomplish a lot of the mundane stuff without pulling your hair out.
- Scavenging. The map is full of useful stuff, and you get to choose how to use it, particularly when it comes to building your base.
- Replay value. This relates strongly to the first point dealing with choices, but because almost everything can pivot the game in at least a small way, things can be very different depending on what you choose.
- Performance. My machine is definitely middle-of-the-pack, but it has no issue running this game with several different background apps.
- Active development. The developers just released a major patch today that implements online co-op, and they've been regular about updates and bug fixes since launch.

There are some things to be aware of that some people won't find that attractive.
- The graphics are very basic, but it's by design.
- The crafting system is rudimentary, but you also don't have to pull your hair out putting things together.
- Music gets a bit repetitive.

Seriously, for the money, it's going to be very difficult to get a game that rivals all you can enjoy here. Really well done!

reviewText:
I will have to preface this review with this one line:  This is literally the first game in over 2 years I am excited to come home and play.

Survivalist is an RPG/RTS hybrid, with sandbox elements baked in.  You start off as Joe, a financial hedge fund manager who has no practical skills and a boatload of worthless money, who lives in a 3x3 meter concrete bunker.  As you start, the game takes you through its tutorial phase, and I found it to be a quite easy to understand.  It covers most, if not all you need to learn about the game.  In about 1-2 hours you will learn how to build your base, scavenge for loot, and shoot zombies in style.

However, this game shows its detail even in the tutorial, as you can completely skip it, and the game will remember this and assume you know the game, giving you full control over all functions.  It will also remember that you didn't get a certain community member and have certain events unfold!

But this is only the beginning of the game.  From there, you can quest by yourself or with a posse, forgo exploration and build your base and community, or build relations with not only the friendly communities but also the various looter or highwaymen gangs.  I found it a nice touch to be able to recruit what you would expect to be basic bad guys"

reviewText:
Great game concept. Author managed to get together elements of RTS, RPG and survival games to create well balanced and very pleasant game experience.

You build a base and run (very basic) agriculture, scavenge supplies, explore the world and fill quests, developing your character. And, of course, fight zombies. Or other survivors.

There are several shortcomings in each of these areas - low budget really shows - but game gave me (and I believe it will give to any old school RPG positive player) tens of hours of entertainment.

Definitely must buy for a price and I will be definitely on lookout for more games from this author (Survivalist 2?).

reviewText:
First of all I want to say… this game was just not for me, and so to people who know my likes well and have similar tastes, I would not recommend it. However, I can appreciate that although it may not be for me, it is actually a fairly good game and people who don’t have the same miffs with it that I do might really enjoy it (and actually have).

That said, let’s get on with the review.

Joe Wheeler, a self-centered businessman, leaves the safety of his bunker in search for food just about a year after the zombie apocalypse. The game is actually pretty run-of-the-mill post apocalyptic survival game, you have to scavenge, avoid looters, kill/escape zombies, build your own place in the world and overall just survive.

The graphics are pretty good, not 3D masterpieces but I rather like the look of them; the game runs perfectly on older computers and the sounds and music are pretty alright as well.

The Good:

The game has lots of potential, and for being a one-man job, it’s really an amazing accomplishment on the developer’s part.

The world seems to be quite large, the quests, although rather typical, are alright; the quest givers do remember your actions and any misstep will have consequences. You can go to war with factions, recruit people to your side, etc. You can use diplomacy, buy, sell, trade…

The characters do seem to have some form of distinct personalities, and they are flawed in them. I really loved the touch of one of them having diabetes, it brought realism to the story. That there is a limited supply of insulin you must find/trade for also made it more realistic. But it also has the downside of making you feel truly rushed…

You can split your party and give everyone commands. You can build things and plant crops.

It has a fatigue system so you can’t just run forever, and I rather like that they added a needed sleep schedule to the hunger/thirst part of surviving.

People can actually leave your party/settlement/faction when they don’t like you anymore.

You can save at any time during the game, something that always wins my heart.


The Bad:

The default controls are super uncomfortable to me. Having to click F1 for the inventory is a stretch, using the middle button (mouse wheel button) to skip text is super uncomfortable. Entering a building is done through clicking with the mouse, but so is talking, and the menu for talking pops up as soon as someone is next to you, so sometimes the characters would stand right next to me when I was trying to enter a building which ended up in me talking to them when I didn’t want to.
Overall it was a pain to do half the things I had to do.

The characters who didn’t have a high shooting skill couldn’t shoot straight worth a damn. I get it this was probably going for realism, even Joe outright admits that he’s a bad shot. But there’s a bad shot, and there’s I-can’t-hit-a-target-even-when-it’s-on-me. The zombies were just way too fast and the aiming did not work quite as well when you had to be moving around all the time to avoid them jumping you from far too far. I found 0 melee weapons on the time I played (I honestly don’t know if there’s any), which admittedly wasn’t much. It was disturbing. I’d expect you’d find a baseball bat to smash a zombie’s head with before you’d find a gun…Then again I suppose since it’s a year later most people would be carrying guns… all the same, a backup melee weapon would have been nice to find.

The game’s inventory is handled by a weight system, which is alright. However, it feels like you can’t really accomplish anything because everything you find to carry weighs too much and you end up having to make some very tough choices. This could be fine if you like a hard challenge, I’d rather get a bit more time to enjoy the game while surviving…

Resource hunting is mind numbingly boring. Just getting the things to start building a fence took forever. Even with a backpack, because of the weight issue, the character can only bring one or two pieces of wood at a time. While realistic, this was also terribly frustrating - It takes longer to bring a piece of wood back to the shelter than it takes my characters to start getting hungry and sleepy and thirsty.

The need for food/sleep/water/insulin seems too pressing. Again, good if you’re playing say, hard mode, but it doesn’t let you (or at least, wasn’t letting me) enjoy the game. I wasn’t even done figuring out a quest, and already they were starving. (Ok, not starving-starving, but already quite hungry).

The AI seemed clunky when you left your guys alone. I left one doing the supply runs for wood so I could start building up something, he was attacked and bitten because I wasn’t there to press space when he got jumped. Had to restart because I was unable to get the needed antigen and I was fairly sure I couldn’t lose my only builder so far.



All in all, while I loved the general premise and style of Survivalist, I couldn’t bring myself to fully enjoy the game as I felt rushed to get through it, and annoyed with the controls; yet I can see lots of potential in it. I was pretty split on recommending this game or not. In the end I’m going with a tentative “no” because to me the cons are a bit more annoying than the pros. Still, I can admit it's not a bad game.

So, if you like a challenge in your survival games, then I would definitely recommend Survivalist to you. For the price it can be a great game. If you were expecting something a little more relaxed, I wouldn’t recommend it.

There is word that there might be a multiplayer mode added, and I’m looking forward to see if it makes it any easier on the players by teaming up.

* Key provided by Developer

reviewText:
tl;dr Worth it.

So you're a hedge fund manager and you decide to buy up a bunch of land in the desert and construct a bunker and stock it full of food and supplies. Then Zday kicks off and you're living easy. Well that got you through the first hump but your supplies have run out. Now it's time to venture out and resupply and hopefully reconnect with whatever remains of civilization.

What you find, rather unfortunately, is an emotional train wreck of a woman with an insulin problem who badgers you constantly and sets off warning bells every time her blood sugar gets too high. Then some pointless quests that are all focused on getting said waste-of-space woman more insulin so that she can complain again later that she's out. I've thought about kicking her out of the group so many times...

That aside, you meet some interesting people and convince them to join you. Together you make a small community, build up some walls, put up a tower or two, some crops, a well, a few houses.. before you know it, you've got the sparks of a community you can call yours. you set the guard rotations, make sure your crops are being tended to, and put together an A Team of badasses with some heavy packs to loot the hell out of the desert. Let the good times roll.

At 10 hours in I have just barely gotten to that point, and there is so much more to do... This game rocks. The controls are a bit funky (on 360 controller and/or mouse/keyboard) but you get used to them. Some of the interaction menus come up at the complete wrong times and can cause you to die, so my suggestion is to save often to avoid that. The graphics are great for this game and help with emersion. The music ranges from good and very fitting to the horrible non-stop out of place techno music that tends to give me a headache. I usually just save the game then reload the save to force a new song to go on. Some people complain about the reputation grinding, but it's not that bad. So you have to talk to a few people, do some work for them (which also gets you gold), and gift them an item... isn't that how it works in the real world too? It's completely fine.

All around great game and for only $4.99 it's an instant buy if it's already on your wish list. So far I've gotten $0.50 an hour of enjoyment in my 10 hours of play and can easily see another 20-30 hours... Worth it.

reviewText:
the animations are really good for a 5$ indie game. I don't think it will have too much replayability.. i'm only a few hours in and i'm just now starting to contruct my base. overall my first 2 hours were really exciting.. it's fast paced, you can bleed out if you get scratched don't have bandages. good amount of items; pistol, shotgun, assualt rifle i've found so far.. it's a neat game.. if you're into zombie games like state of decay, it's worth 5$. Medical supplies can be traded for at NPC towns for gold. You find random items off the zombies and looters you kill. It's not a waste of money in my honest opinion. Try the demo out if you have any fears.

Pro's
-Free form construction of base, you decide where you build your walls one block at a time. also other buildings like guard houses, out houses, and houses for your npcs.
-Other NPC bases to trade with/ attack/ loot/ or ally.. you decide.
-Awesome action, npc's fight on their own. cool 2nd fight screen that shows everything in 3d around you.. it's really neat.
-Easy to cycle between NPC's
-Your builder will gather materials needed to complete project from the town without your supervision. Someone said they needed consant micromanagement, which was a total lie/lazy on their part. there is a bit of micromanaging between the two.. but it's not crazy time consuming.
-RPG elements, skills increase with usage and time
-NPC towns
-Random events like Looters attacking your base, and zombie hordes coming for you
-Farming and ways to stay sustainable
-Enemies respawn after time, areas you clear of zombies will become dangerous again.


Con's
- the map is a very decent size, don't get me wrong. But i wish it were bigger..
-probably something like 14-15 hours of gameplay


I love the game just wish it had more random generation and a sandbox mode for infinite gameplay.



*** there is a cheat mode to add npc's and respawn towns with looters and other enemies. This would add more gameplay.

reviewText:
First Impressions:

This is a top-down action light RPG set in a post-apocalyptic world (with zombies, looters, and other communities). To quickly sum up what you can do, you can switch characters, loot houses (you cannot view the insides), manage inventories, send survivors on automatic supply runs, eat/drink/sleep/medicate to prevent from dying, build a base, embark on missions, trade using gold as a currency, and more.  I'm admittedly not that far into it, but so far I'm having a pretty good time with it.  There's a lot here for $5, though the combat can be a little too overwhelming at times...that is, zombies can run and mission difficulty can spike to impossible levels.  Despite its faults, it's a game you can easily pump four hours into (probably more), making it worth the price of admission.

reviewText:
Great game, especially at this price point. Not one crash or bug encountered in 16 hours of game play.

Combat is fast and fun. Controls are intuitive. Controlling each individual survivor as well as being able to command them in command mode for repetitive tasks (like go get the 60 boards from that hardware store, 2 at a time) is very nice. The base building aspect is great. Roaming zombies and looters makes having some guards in guard towers useful.

You can recruit pretty much anyone with the right approach, including the enemy looters in camps that people in towns tell you to kill. Getting them all to join you seems to work just as well as killing them, at least in the missions I've done so far.

Quick tip for newbies: Try fighting green zombies hand to hand. Not only does it save bullets, it builds your fitness skill - which lets you carry more (much more with a good backpack) and keep the tougher zombies off you better. Just make sure not to sprint your stamina away before a fight, hand to hand does basically no damage when fatigued and you can't kick the zombies off you either. Once your skill is higher you can even fight off the tougher zombies with hand to hand.

Another plus to having high fitness is you can do the boxing thing with npcs, which builds respect for you in addition to giving you money. I think high fitness even helps with making the NPCs who try to shake you down back off if you stand up to them (big buff guy more intimidating I guess). With a high fitness I was able to walk into a looter camp and shake down one of them, then recruit him forcibly and everyone else just by asking since they are now impressed with the way I handled myself.

reviewText:
I got tons of entertainment out of these 5 €. The game is finished and still there are updates providing new features (like additional save slots and coop play to name just the latest). That speaks volumes for how the dev is approaching this game.

I won't go into the gameplay features in detail, others have done that extensively. So I'll just give the tl;dr:

Of course there are a few handling problems and the graphics are a bit basic. But the gameplay is sound, basebuilding is very entertaining and the story and missions are quite interesting.

And even if after a while there isn't really anything that can threaten your base (if you set up right) it is still a challenge to keep your resource gatherers alive.

I have spent ten times the amount I payed for this game on pieces of eyecandy I dropped after 20 hrs. In comparison I have now spend almost 150 hrs on my two playthroughs of Survivalist.

8/10 no ragrets

reviewText:
Hahahaha !  HAHA!! HAHAHAHAHA !!! HA !  HA !  HAHAAHA !!

This game is -awesome- !

I've only played about an hour so far, but even if it sucks from this point onward, it's still more than worth my five bucks.  It's great!  It's so unique and weird.  I love the little cinematic camera that traps everything going on around you in 3D, it's a little bit like watching a bad 80s zombie movie.

This game oozes so much personality, I might just catch a social disease from it.

Seriously, if you're even half thinking of it, buy the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

I've gotten enough fun out of the last hour that it doesn't matter where the game goes .. although I do have the impression that there's a bit of depth to it .. crafting, base building, long-term survival .. but I'm still muddling through early game.

UPDATE (2 weeks later):
Okay, so I've been playing a bunch of games - so many in the library, but Survivalist has been able to lure me pretty consistently.  So it isn't just a great first reaction, it's a great game overall.  Later on you get into politics and quests and drama with other survivors inside and outside your community, you get to grow your community, build a base, defenses, farm, etc.  I was surprised by how much depth the game has (as the graphics are a bit arcade-y).  There's a learning curve, but once you master the systems, you can assign all kinds of cool roles to your community members - farmer, scavenger, guard, etc ... and the AI is surprisingly good.

8/10 overall

reviewText:
OK 6 hours in and I feel like I'm slowly turning into a green zombie myself. I really REALLY love this game.

For me graphics aren't very important. I always compare to the film industry - there are so many shallow, big budget, gorgeous looking, but TERRIBLE films coming out ever since we had the technology to make them.

However I am old school and graphics are meaningless compared to story, gameplay and how much you get sucked into a game.

Yes you can get the odd title with all of the above including graphics, but you can't get them for the tiny sum these guys are asking.

This game is deep, with plenty of fun quests that keep you playing and playing. It has some great base building gameplay which can take place independently at the same time as you are out shooting up the world, thanks to having programmable community members to build, farm and collect materials.

You can build up your community and its members as you like, finding people with the required skills or training them up and hopefully keeping them alive. You can test your strategic skills by assaulting enemy camps or defending bases that you have designed completely yourself.

Everyone you meet will have their own opinion of you depending on how you interact with them and the people they care about, affecting trade prices and available missions. You can lay waste to other communities or slowly recruit them all away to your base, or leave them intact as valuable outposts for trade and supplies in the middle of the wasteland. You can be as good or totally evil as you like and reap the consequences or rewards!

You always need to keep moving and exploring to find the resources required to keep your people alive and it just draws you in!

On the downside I did find the controls slightly clumsy and difficult to use in places to begin with, but it was quickly overcome. I would like to be able to change the camera angle though, unless I haven't found this yet. Also to start with I wasn't paying attention properly when placing buildings, so my first watchtower was the wrong way around and open and exposed to everyone beyond the wall! (not sure if this is actually reflected with defense penalties) I would like a feature to be able to rotate the buildings after building them without deleting them (although not realistic).

I haven't tried co-op but I am really a single game player so my review would be meaningless on this.

All in all you can really get completely absorbed into this world and these guys prove you don't have to have a VR set + next gen visuals to do that!
voteText: 15 of 16 people (94%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Survivalist have some of the most interesting gameplay I have encountered in years. Zombie survival horror at it's very best, and it is far cheaper than it ought to be and similar titles. I suggest people try the demo, and then decide. I for one find it to be the best money spent on a game the last year. Do not get scared by the somewhat archaic looking graphics.

Bob have maneged to single-handedly create a game that surpass most industry titles in gameplay, story and even character building. And, I am already looking forward to the next playthrough, with some different choices. Works wonders as a sandbox game too.

The game-mechanics are good and functional, the game practically bug free (for me).

Others critics have mentioned micro-manegement as somewhat of a hazzle at endgame, but the last community I built was over a 100 people, and it did not take as much micro management as I feared. It depends on playstyle I suspect. Most of the time, my people did their things without supervision. That said, there is manegement required, it ain't abojut the shoot, hack and slash.

That said for my only grievance, hopefully future improvements will see optimization of the community member list, so you can sort by skill to pick the right survivor for a job. It took a lot of memory and notes to find that former looter who supposedly were great at farming, but needed that watering can you just found.

I recommend the game, and encourage people to support Bobs efforts, as he really got something quite unique here.

reviewText:
A great game with a great potential.
It has interesting ideas, intense and gripping gameplay, catchy music. And last, but not least, it has a certain depth to it. Characters remember what you did to them, moral dilemmas aren't black-and-white and building your own community is a great game mechanic overall.
Compared to slow and boring Dead State fast and addicting Survivalist is a masterpiece.
For what it's worth - Survivalist is a wonderful little game.
voteText: 20 of 28 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Quite a neat little polished game. Basically it's an open world sandbox in the vain of Project Zomboid. You start off in a bunker and go exploring to find food/water and other supplies. Along the way you'll meet friendly NPCs and settlements, as well as enemy raiders and of course Zombies. You can recruit other NPCs to follow you (and become playable characters), and eventually establish your own settlement wherever you like really. This settlement can be built up with walls, houses, towers etc.\n\nInventory management plays a big part in this game with some tasks taking a while to complete without having large backpacks equipped on your characters. You can automate tasks by telling your characters to go collect wood/water/other supplies so in a sense it has an RTS element too as this is all controlled from a top down perspective. Combat is simple yet functional with bullets being relatively scarce, and the enemies are quite varied with raiders being tough to kill while zombies are cliched being simple in small groups but quite difficult in hordes.  There are way more features I have not touched on but if you want a really pleasing survival game with a pick up and play aspect to it, then Survivalist is that!

reviewText:
VERDICT: For the most part I found Survivalist to be a very solid and enjoyable game.  On first appearances it may seem like a casual version of Dead State-lite but its not even turn-based. If you are a fan of State of Decay then you will be pleased to find a number of similarities with that game.

Its a zombie survival RPG played in real-time with exploration, combat, character fatigue/hunger/ thirst, community recruitment, base building, tied together with some complex quests.  Unfortunately there are a few really frustrating things such as overly complex quest-arcs, somewhat frenetic combat and some very gamey aspects to recruiting and achievement hunting that bring it slightly down from being great.

Overall the game possesses some really well designed and implemented features which together add up to surpass the sum of its parts.  However it can be difficult to get into if you dont enjoy the feeling of not being in complete control.  If you are not great at multi-tasking or you dislike the pace and frantic nature of real-time combat then I would give this a miss or dont expect too much!

Those things almost put me off during my first aborted playthrough.  Yet if you can overlook them or possess a methodical approach to gameplay there's a very good game to discover.   One that surprised me but only if you have the patience and persistence to try.


... More info below ...


01. GENRE: Story-driven, zombie survival isometric RPG.  Played in real-time.

02. SETTING: A post-apocalypic scenario full of rival communities in a fictional desert region around mid-west United States.

03. STORY/BACKGROUND: Take control of Joe Wheeler a successful hedge fund manager (i.e. tosser) who built his own bunker before the zombie apocalypse started.  After a year of surviving alone and with dwindling resources, its time to take your first steps into a harsh new world, recruit characters, form a community, build a base, gather resources and complete quests, while fighting bands of looters and avoiding infection from zombies.

The story is fairly deep, with a complex main quest.  One that demands your full attention otherwise you can lose your bearings and get bored.  This is further complicated with the time sensitive nature of the insulin quest and your need to find more of it to keep a certain NPC alive.  Unfortunately there is also at least one convoluted quest where you have to wait, wait and wait for someone to die (if you dont want bad karma) to get an item you may desparately need [for more insulin].  These plain suck and take away from the satisfying quests.

04. GAME MODES: A multiple story driven campaign played out on a single map with around two dozen quest arcs of varying length, complication and effort.  The main story arc has about 20 sub-quests to complete.  The core gameplay will take in excess of 50hours easily.  My playthrough took 90hours and it was far from comprehensive.  If you fail a quest you are given the chance to reload automatically.

05. GAME/LEVEL DESIGN: The whole game takes place on one explorable map populated by survivor communities, zombies, deserted towns and looters.  The map is not fully open-world restricting exploration through the the nature of the insulin quest and the need to keep an eye on your community members.  The game can be continued after the main quest is finished.  If you are lucky you can attempt to complete the other two alternatives to the central quest.

06. GAMEPLAY/MECHANICS: An almost perfect blend of features for the genre. Contains a good number of well conceived multi-option quests, well-rounded and flawed characters and a clever dialogue system even though sometimes gamey recruitment requirements for key characters - such as luring zombies near to them to increase respect.

There is also excellent base building and community management, substantial item inventory, and a good RPG-lite stats for each character that determine key actions such as fitness, combat, construction, healing and farming.  Combat is frenetic in real-time which was hit and miss and, a fairly robust A.I. that allows you delegate tasks to community members even if it was not perfect.  Resource collection was a tad too slow, making the game last too long.

07. ENEMIES: Zombies are unfortunately not the main threat in the game.  They exist alone or in small groups in unexplored areas.  They will try to run and bite your characters either alone or in groups until despatched.   Once the fog of war is exposed those areas are clear. Humans come in two forms: survivors and looters.  Combat doesnt necessarily need to occur with humans but once you start they will remain hostile until they are dead.  These attack with numerous weapons and in groups so are much more dangerous.  However periodically the groups of roving zombies and looters will target your base to keep you on your toes.

08. A.I: The game possess some solid A.I.  It allows you to manage what tasks individuals are assigned, while having them seek; food, water and rest when they require it.  They will even hunt down ammo if they are low.  The A.I. was so well-made that the paltry issues I had were that farmers did not collect and store corn and if water wasnt available, they did not seek it from nearby wells.   Combat is straightforward enough, as they will shoot any perceived threat or attempt to kick them off if overwhelmed.

09. CONTROLS: Fine but not completely initutive for a PC user.

10. GRAPHICS: Basic.  Cartoony in nature but clear and good enough for the job.

11. SOUNDTRACK & AUDIO: Unintrusive.  Firearms and reloading sounds are satisfying.

12. VOICE ACTING: None.  But the well-written dialogue compenstates.

13. CHALLENGE/DIFFICULTY: Easy to pick-up.  Not so easy to manage the party as it grows.  Its main difficult is determining the right course of actions to complete the quests in hand.  Combat also presents its challenges when faced with better equipped enemies.

14. PROBLEMS: No problems running the game experienced.

15. ACHIEVEMENTS: These are wide ranging.  Only a few are simple.  Some are overly complex.  If you are expecting easy and fast achievements this is not the game for you.  There are a couple that are insanely difficult to get and very time consuming!  On the other hand when you do trigger one its very satisfying.  Some of the achievements will need at least one replay.  Likely more.

16. DLC: None but a sequel is planned by the developer.  Yes I said developer.  It was made [mostly] by one person!  So kudos to him for a sterling effort!

17. ONLINE PLAY/COMMUNITY: Did not try co-op but I would imagine if its stable the game would be twice as engrossing to play with two of you in the same group.

18. ENJOYMENT/APPEAL: For a real-time RPG and indie game this really surprised me.  It has alot of great content even if only the main quest is replayable.  I think fans of games with the story and questing of Baldurs Gate and Icewind Dale, and the zombie survival and party/base management of State of Decay, Dead State wil definitely enjoy Survivalist.  Even if it appears to be the poor relation graphically.

19. PLAYTIME/LONGEVITY/REPLAYABILITY: The game is built for at least one playthrough but given the complicated nature of the quest arcs and the all to real possibility of messing up something you could be playing this twice or three times as there are three possible player sanctioned goals that require the best part of the game to slowly achieve.  These are: Love, Money and Power.  Each has its own set of sub-quests you will really need to make and to some extent grinding goals to chip away at as you play.

20. VALUE FOR MONEY: One of the few titles I would recommend at full price.  Getting it on a sale would just be a bonus.

reviewText:
I'll not spend too much time echoing what others have said.  Instead, I'll draw your attention to a key choice the game has you focus on:

As you can see from the official trailer, Alice Ivers has type 1 diabetes and will die if she doesn't get her insulin.  Getting that insulin is something close to a full time job.  You have complete control over Alice and could easily march her off into the desert to die.  Or you grit your teeth, double down, and get one more syringe to get through one more day.

It's honestly a tough call, and you don't find decisions like that in games these days.

Good stuff.

reviewText:
Okay, so I have played about 38 hours worth of this game now.

In short, I like it, and it's dirt cheap!

You start out with the main protagonist, a hedge fund manager, with no great skill, no weapons, a few packets of chips, some water and some bandages. You leave the bunker, only to be attacked while looking for your car. You beat up the zombie, take his gun and ammo, and from then on, get ready to shoot some Zombies.

But the main focus of this game really isn't on the Zombie shooting. You need to find other survivors, entice them to join you through various methods, and slowly build a community. You can build buildings, fortifications, farm food, draw water from the well you dug, and most importantly, trade and scavenge for food and other supplies.

The game becomes increasingly harder, giving thougher Zombies and looters to fight while you solve various quests and increase your numbers.

By now I have plenty food, water, ammo and a completely build camp with walls and towers, and most importantly about 10 inhabitants.

And still, I haven't seen the entire map yet, or found all the challenges to come.

Great game, especially when you consider the price!
voteText: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is the Zombie game I've been waiting for since the genre exploded. It is a superbly well thought out game and contains a perfect mix of RPG, Base building and Adventure.

RPG: Characters level up. They improve as they carry out the actions in several different areas. You can also purchase books which improve their skill whilst in the inventory. Your actions are remembered by NPCs too and their opinion of you is fluid throughout the game based upon your actions.

Base Building: This is just sublime. Yes, the buildings are generic templates, but you can buid those fences, fortifcations and such however and wherever you like. One very minor point is that it's fairly tricky to build anywhere other than the default place, but as mentioned before, what you do to enhance it and how, that's very much up to you.

Adventure: There are storylines! You have to curry favour with various individuals and factions. This can open up other questlines, and you can even persuade them to join your cause. I believe prices charged by vendors for items can be swayed this way too.

This truly is a magnificent game. Until this game came along, State of Decay was probably the closest to 'realism' and sense of survival against the odds with dwindling supplies. This, for me, while it doesn't perhaps look quite as gorgeous to look at, is infintely better it almost all other aspects of the game.

Since buying it I've hardly gotten any housework done, and I've contemplating phoning in sick at work!

The developer seems to be a one man team - and he is very active on forums, answering questions and discussing feedback. Can't wait for Survivalist 2 (PLEASE MAKE IT HAPPEN!)

Thoroughly recommended.

reviewText:
Erm why do my hours dont add up? anywho its a good zombie survival game with a decent story line and well highly recommended for the price range. It doesn't need a powerful computer to run and I think your grandpa's pc will be sufficient as well.

You start solo and then can expand into a community which enables you to control any character in your group. Yes, you do need to gather food supplies, ammo, water and well medical supplies like any other zombie survival game by either scavenging or trading with other npcs. What I like most about this game is the challenge it might provide as well as the little details the developer managed to fit in such a light game. One of the initial, rather a major character suffers from diabetes so you need to find some specific medicines for her from time to time. As you over use a character, it becomes tired and end up being less productive so you are forced to shuffle which is a POSITIVE here. You can kill any character and decide if you want to complete a mission or not. It has base building which is pretty straight forward and unlike other games, it takes real man hours to complete construction (an NPC fetches resources and builds).

I could go in detail (not really) but lets keep it short. Using steam rating logic I rate this game 11 out of 10.

reviewText:
A HIDDEN GEM.

I was very surprised by this game. Survivalist is a top down post-apocalyptic RPG similar to State of Decay and Dead State. Set one year into the zombie apocalypse you start off as a wealthy business man with heaps of worthless money who has been living alone in a bunker for a whole year hoping to wait out the apocalypse, but then your bunker supplies unexpectedly ran out. Left with no choice but to venture outside you will encounter other survivors, zombies, looters and so your adventure begins in this zombified desert wasteland.

The game is not perfect but it is still very fun to play. The graphics are pretty dated; they look like The Sims 2 from 2004 level of graphics but with better shadow effects. But this is probably due to the game be ported over from old Xbox 360 hardware, which also limits the frame rate to about 30 so that may turn some people off. Also the aiming is off as you cannot pull off any headshots against your enemies which makes gun combat pretty annoying in early game where your character's firearms skills are low and can lead to some pretty cheap deaths with your characters. Also ammo and supplies are plentiful in this game which can take away some of the hardcore survival aspects of this game.

But the positives out-way the negatives, gameplay is still fun and there is a lot to see and do, there is a good package here for just $5. If you enjoy zombie games like State of Decay which is also similar, then you will have no serious problems with this game.

Survivalist has my seal of approval.

reviewText: This is quite literally one of the BEST indie games i have EVER played. It made it into my top 5 and it should be in yours if its not already. This game has so much content i was baffled that it only cost 5 dollars. The game lets you choose your own goals which effect the storyline, theres fantastic combat, zombies dont respawn which some might consider a negative but i actually like that since you can effectively set up safe zones where theres no threat of attack, but even then if you enter a major township a pack of zombies or lotters might pick up your scent and follow you back to your base. The looting is amazing, i was always excited to see what new buildings held and what i was gunna bring home with me. The character interaction is top notch, you can switch to any player in your community at any time and control them as you would the main character, and so the character you currently control will have different views of different people and people outside your community will see that character differently than your main character, which makes character selection when interacting with other communities very important. Lastly, the build up to the final fight and the final fight itself with los ceros is amazing. I was losing it trying to make sure that everyone in my community was geared up for a good fight, and we certaintly had a good fight which was quite satisfying. I'll say it now, I WANT ANOTHER!!!! Gimme a damn sequel and i'll play the hell out of it. I LOVE THIS GAME! I will support it to the ends of the earth and you should to! This game is just 5 bucks and youll get countless hours of fun out of it so what the hell are you waiting for? GET IT!!!!

reviewText: Every time I'm playing this I feel like I'm playing a part of The Walking Dead series which is pretty cool. Granted there are things missing such as Daryl's crossbow, but Survivalist captures the overall feeling of trying to survive against zombies  looters and the like.\n\nThis game is hard though, and not everything is intuitive, so it takes a while to get used to. But once you get into it, you look at efficiency: How can I minimise the trips I need to carry these wood planks? Farm up lots of food? Take out these looters with minimum injuries? It's a great game, one of the best indie games, made by a single person. Play it!

reviewText:
A fantastic game. I was slow to playing and finishing it, I never had much time to play games these days.

I finally got around to it now, 50 hours in 2 weeks or so, and I feel positive about the ending that I followed.

-The game allows you to build a new thriving society however and where ever you want in the game world, but you're limited to the supplies you have and can find.

-Zombies. It is a zombie survival game but it's not boring. It has an interesting and depressing story behind it where there are no right answers.

-Karma. A Karma like system exist in which NPCs will either like you or hate you to a certain degree. Some will like you so much that the price of items go down while those who hate you will leave your community or outright attack you.

-Scavenge. It wouldn't be a survival game without some scavenging involved. Set up supply routes with your survivors to keep your flow of wood, wire, and cement going strong. Be wary of Looter Gangs and Infected Hordes that emerge from the small towns.

-Control or command. Control each survivor in your community individually or command them as a group as you would an RTS. Issue orders such as Guard, Farm, or Supply run to keep them busy. Don't worry about their needs. If they need food, water or sleep, they can do so themselves and return to their assigned duties. I found it useful to have a larger community with good fighters to cover the Watch Towers. So say 10 Watch Towers, with 20 Guards on shifts. One guard goes to sleep the others take their place. Giving the community 24/7 protection from anyone or anything sneaking in, and the buggers do manage to sneak in if you're not careful.

-Story. There is a story involved and it's good. You meet your main character Joe Wheeler, likely of Captain Planet fame which explains why he's so despicable. He survived in a Bunker for a year but now needs to venture out. He meets a damsel in distress. Ok cool, what does she need? Oh that's easy. Kill her sister... well she's infected so good news. Bad news is telling her she's infected. I am joking. Now Alice Ivers plays as your secondary main. Her Chat options are much kinder than Wheelers and will achieve more friendships than Wheeler will who is better off as an imposing figure to intimidate people to his will. Finally we meet the third character who players only use to build the base. Isham Seely, the sole survivor of his community who joins up to assist in helping Alice with her problem. She needs Insulin and there isn't a lot to go around.

So now with Wheeler as a fighter, Alice as a healer, and Isham as a builder, you're off to a great start to playing this game the best to your ability to swindle, convince, fight, and manipulate others, or, are you being manipulated yourself by those you trust the most? Honestly, I trust the Antagonists of this game more than I do any one else. At least they're honest about what they do.

After 85 hours now, I feel accomplished. What an experience and for a very low price. This is a survival game that doesn't get boring so easily. The map isn't too big, there are over 400+ characters with their own stories and needs, and you can choose to help them or kill them outright. You can build your home where you need it to be or build multiple homes. Burn homes down, take over territories, whatever. It was a blast and I cannot recommend it anymore than I can right now.

I never knew this game was going to be so damn good.

reviewText: I Have spent a few good hours on this game and felt it worthy of writing a rewiew. I have enjoyed this title so far, Even thought I feel like the controls are made for a controller more than a keyboard every thing is still responds smoothly. There are a lot of interactions with NPC in this game, some of the dialog is very funny, and what you choose to say can affect the story. I have found this game to be one of those that you better save often or youll find yourself loosing a few hours of game play because you saved three hours before you got infected, or injured. I like the NPC team control in this game. You must keep track of your survivors health and sleep statistics, or at least make sure they have food and water available to eat and drink themselves. You can send survivors in different directions and on different quest at the same time. There is a system that allows you to give orders and the survivors will use their own AI to complete the task given. So far I have one fetching water, one fetching wood, and the other is completeing the story quest. Ammo is sometimes hard to come by in this game and youll need a lot of it to level your firearm skills. Dont allow the infected to bite you as the antigen is hard to come by and is very expensive. I think this game has a neat User Interface it is simple I really enjoy the action camera view in the UI. So far what ive explored of the map is pretty fun, not knowing whats ahead always makes things tense however I feel that the survivors would be able to see a bit further than they are able to in the game, but then they wouldn't have so many suprise infected moments.\n\nFor those who are looking for a fun single player game with a good setting,story, and action then I can easily reccommend this game. If you are wanting a sandbox, openworld, build it yourself then I reccommend 7 Days to Die because this is a different type of game. I have had no issues with performance on this game either everything worked very smooth from the beginning. I am using Windows 7 x64 and Radion HD 5450 series video card. Overall I could easily give this game a 9/10 score. The only reason it didn't get 10 is every good game can use more content, or even a coop player mode right?

reviewText: This game is fantastic.  A full game (no lame DLC or disgusting micro-transactions) at a fair price.  Everyone should support this kind of game development.  This is a zombie survival game that you can actually win!  In fact, you have a choice of three winning conditions, making the game a replayable instant indie classic.  With better production values than many AAA games, this gave is clearly a labor of love on behalf of its designer.  A developer who cares about the quality of his or her game is a rarity in this era of broken releases and Early Access rip-offs.  Support this game, and you won't be disapointed.

reviewText:
I was expecting buggy 90's gaming throwbacks based on the screenshots. And it's a yet another wombie-game...
But the positive reviews and the low price during the Summer Sale convinced me to pick it up and give it a whirl.

I've been whirling since. I have been playing several hours and still can't decide whether I should continue exploring or expanding my base. Or moving my base elsewhere? I wouldn't know. I'm too wrapped up in this game and its surprisingly suspenseful gameplay.

This is more of a RPG than an action game, but you can't win on auto-pilot: you need a strategy and some decent reflexes. Or the firepower to make up for it. I can't even create a coherent review now that I'm not playing. I'm thinking of strategies to build and strengthen my community without invoking war...

The map has its limits but it looks pretty big and the side-quests seem endless, so this game will probably have me hooked for a good 100 hours or so. By far the best game I've picked up this Summer Sale.

reviewText:
A very well made game. The graphic and layout may gives an impression of a cheap and sub par game but when you try it, you know you were wrong. Well, after you finished the tutorial of course. The first few hours of the game might be boring but if you stick to it until you get your base, that's the real fun and action really starts.

Pro:
- Nice story. It is not a blockbuster, but it is not as simple as save-the-damsel-in-distress-but-she-is-in-another-castle linear type of story.
- Nice implementation of RPG gameplay. You start weak, you end strong. You start poor, you end rich. You start with fist, you end with a rocket launcher. You start alive, you end dead, at least couple of time for me near the end.
- Nice action/combat. It's kinda simplistic, but fits well with the gameplay. Some people dislike the targeting system where with the lowest skill, you can even miss at melee distance. For me it is done well as you can improves it with firearm skill. It's better than not being able to use certain weapon due to not meeting the requirement. You want to use a rifle? You can, but you'll waste lots of rifle bullets. If the rifle bullets are too precious, keep using the gun until you get better with your aiming.
- Nice enemy. Some people dislike the infected being able to detect you from distance and ambush you. I think that's brilliant. It will give you a sense of fear and always be careful when exploring especially new area. It's not zombicalypse if you're not fear for your life. You're not only dealing with zombie, but also with human.
- Adequate partial RTS. You can build a base, or multiple bases. You can provide shelter and create a self sustain community. Fend off gang of raiders or zombies. I would love to have more choice, but it is adequate for the game.
- It's a survival. You need to eat, you need to drink, you need to sleep, you need to make lov...maybe not. Be prepare for your adventure and scavenge as needed.
- Choices you make, affect the game. All those people you kill, all those people you shakedown, all those presents you give, will affect others.
- There are no I'm the kindest

reviewText:
My name is Joe Wheeler, its been 364 days since the end of the world, im out of food and water, tomorrow i will venture onto the surface in search of more.

So i walked down the road in search of my car, its still there, parked where i left it, but it doesnt work anymore, and not only that but there was a corpse lying beside it. When i ventured closer to the corpse it stood up, so i proceeded to ruin my suit and bash the corpses head in with my bare hands.

The corpse had within its pockets a loaded gun and a large amount of extra ammunition for it. I needed to find a town, and people. My radio let me know of an sos call nearby that i might check out. Probably not, i dont like getting involved with other peoples ♥♥♥♥.

On my way down the road i found another corpse, it stood up yet again, but i was expecting this and i had my new found pistol ready, it took me a few shots, roughly about a clip before i got lucky and put a bullet between the blazing green eyes.

It was quicker and easier than the first corpse, but i still missed alot so i decided to train a bit on a nearby parking sign. I got a few good shots in and decided to continue into the nearby town because that was still the reason i was out here right now.

So i found some food, and decided i would in fact check out that sos call. Who knows, maybe they have some food or something i can have?

I met a girl and killed her sisters corpse, this one had red eyes, i wonder if that means anything, i think it does, all of my shots landed thanks to my training on the sign, but it still took almost 4 entire clips to put her down. The girls started following me around now, apparently she was headed for a different town before she and her sister were attacked by other living corpses.

We ran into another man, he gave us some insulin (the girl turns out to be diabetic, who knew) and offered to help us hold up somewhere, he tells us he knows a thing or two about building, and he'll even gather the supplies himself.

Well not long after, i was just out looking for food and now im lying here bitten and bleeding out quickly. I'm not going any further than this. So i guess this is the end for Joe Wheeler huh? Oh well, lifes a ♥♥♥♥♥ and then you die heh...



These were my first about 20 minutes of survivalist, and i have to say its an excellent game, despite its age and cheap price, its excellent and has a very deep gameplay. By this i mean, its not a tps or an fps, or anything of the sorts. Its a very in depth survival game where food, water, sleep and even insulin are all required to live. It has a good learning curve, as long as your not an idiot like me, where your fairly babied here and there, your first two enemies can barely move, and even if they catch you, just tap space and your fine, but your third enemy, is a sprinting zombie who jumps out of nowhere and tackles you, and moves too quickly to aim your gun at properly, but get tackled 4-5 times without getting a shot in and the game says hey

reviewText:
I admit, originally when i saw this game i thought 'This is a nice concept though it doesn't seem very well executed, also looks kind of strange'. I bought the game thinking 'Might as well give it a try'. I played the game on the edge of my chair trying to keep my survivors alive for just another day. I still haven't stopped playing this game(I'm actually trying to complete a quest as i type this).

Overall, this game is a fresh & interesting combination between a classic topdown zombie survival game, Sims & The Walking Dead.

Pros:
Not purely quest-driven. I've played more than my fair share of zombie games that are 'Go get X object, return the object to Y person, get Z reward and progress in the game'. Survivalist does away with the linear quest-driven system & replaces it with a nice 'Go do it if you want to, or if you don't just don't. We're not going to hold anything away from you if you don't'.

If you're told 'Go and stop this gang' then you also have the choice of assimilating into your group/community instead of just marching in there & murdering everyone

A unique relationship system. Instead of the standard 'i like you, i don't' Survivalist has a twin-axis system of respect and approval. You can make someone do what you want by either making them like you, or fear you. They see you burn their village to the ground single-handedly then they'll fear you, if you save them from being bitten they'll like you.

Well-balanced progressive gamplay that keeps you from becoming too powerful, whilst hard work/dedication/planning pay off greatly

Cons:
40 hours in and I'm yet to find something bad about the game that wasn't caused by oversight or just plain stupidity on my part

reviewText:
This game has complete inovative and never heard before story.. Not...

Hehe, but even though it's about zombies which has been chewed to the death it bring something that should count the most in games world, playability! And this game has it in abundance! I'll try to review it without spoilers :)

It's about John Wheeler, some broker dude who did some fine investments in his life that made possible for him to buy a shelter in the desert.. All hell broke loose, he hid there for one year until his supplies run out and decided to get out of bunker..

That's where you start leading this dude through his adventure. Game is incredible because only one dude made it! And he managed to implement many great aspects like character development, relationships with npc's, trading and even some RTS and building elements!

Like I said, you are John Wheeler, no nonsense dude, who wants to survive zombie outbreak, and (depends of the player decision), achieve his life goal of love/money/power. It has sort of isometric view, game is very fluid, it offers few standard weapons and enemies, and besides outer danger, you have to take care of sleep, hunger and thirst.. So, especially in the beginning, save water and food cans :)

As you progress through the game, it gives you option to make a settlement, recruit people to join your cause, plant corn, build wells etc.. Interesting part is that you can control everyone who is in your settlement/group, so when Wheeler needs to sleep, you just play with other characters..

Almost everyone is expendable"

reviewText:
This game is an arcade like, zombie survival game that substitute the horror with techno rave like music, in other words, humour. The game is highly addictive after you get used to the animation but hey, some of the best games are made in ASCII.

Despite it having maybe some bad traits with the graphics and at times FPS problems, then it is a great find! Easy to understand, hard to solve!

This is an open-world game where you can decide what you want to do. The story is intriguing and gives you a meaning to the world around you, giving you a reason to move and explore the world instead of just surviving. Gather people, become stronger, withstand and survive the vast world!

I highly recommend this game if you just feel like surviving zombie apocalypse with funky techno music, doing whatever you want, saving, taking over or destroying whatever you want, with consequences to doing so. Your choice, you're the big man here.

reviewText:
This game is pretty fun and intuitive as to how it works.  I didn't have any trouble mastering the controls within half an hour.  You die very, very quickly if you don't play properly, but it's easy enough to survive if you plan ahead.  The prices on goods from traders are pretty steep in general, especially medicines.  Food and water can be grown in your settlements, but you can't make medicines or guns/equipment AFAIK.

That being said, however, the soundtrack is awful.  It's very unfitting for a game of this type.

Also, F&*K DIABETES!!!

reviewText:
It catched me in just 3 hours. This review can change in the next days I keep playing, but at the moment I can say it's a deep game.

About the PROS: If you like background stories, there's a lot of microstories as you do  your main quests. As in any other sandbox worth his salt, you can chose to do your quests or just roam for loot and improve your base.

I'm not used at all to play multi-character RPGs so I can say this game makes it easy to control different characters, doing different actions in different parts of the map. That's so enjoyable because you can just ask your stronger man to go and search for heavy supplies for your base while your gardener keeps farming and your firegunner roam killing bandits or doing missions. And you can chose who you control, or you just can take care of them all.

The AI is pretty good despite some path errors, the zombies are hard enough to beat in numbers and easy enough to kill one by one.

The freedom to chose your playstyle as bandit, hero, neutral, or whatever is great -a guy wanted me to pay him 75 coins for a cure of the infection, I bribed him with an item 10-15 coins worth, he now wanted me to pay him just" 73 coins for the cure. I killed him
date:
got a lot of coins and the cure-.

About the CONS: I feel there's so little variety of weapons. It doesn's seem like more will be added since every weapon has already a hotkey number 1-9.

This is not really a negative aspect
