reviewText: As with all open world games, it starts off pretty slowly, leading you through the tutorial with minimal effort. After that, the game seems to slow down. It doesn't of course, but while you've got your main guy out exploring, shooting zombies, etc, the girl you pick up sleeps for about two days (and so you can't do anything with her), and the construction guy (no, not Emmett) walks at a snail's pace between your camp and the local hardware store, bringing back a single plank at a time so he can start building walls, shacks, even toilets.\n\nThat said, this is about the only complaint I have about the game. The rest of it is simple (gameplay, not difficulty), intuitive, and fun. Just... While you're exploring, don't forget to save regularly. It's pretty easy to wander out of your 'safe' zones, and if that happens, you're going to be the one seeking breakfast brains.

reviewText:
For a game made by one person. Its a gem. And at its 5 dollar price, even more so.

The graphics may not be the best, and the AI may need some micromanaging at times, but those aside its an amazing game.

The combat feels like an arcade shooter (Which I mean in a good way) and the base building is both solid and enjoyable. I've found myself redoing aspects of my base to try and better equip myself for raider attacks.

Scavanging is simple and can be done in a number of ways, sending people in your community to auto walk stuff or sending teams of people in you control to get it done quicker, your choice.

The story is great too. Could use some polishing and personal variety with the characters, but otherwise very solid.

With that said, its hard to find a game that offers what this game does for the price it is. Go get it.

reviewText:
Most likely the best value I've gotten for 4,99€ EVER. It contains so much content and gameplay. The RPG system with decisions and reputation works very well (your choices to matter), action is simple and easy to understand, yet extremely entertaining. Society growth and base building is really fun and the storyline is interesting. Food and supplies are scarce and requires effort to gather which makes the survival aspect of the game feel real. Since online co-op mode is on the rise aswell, this game is looking to become one of the better survivalist projects out there in my opinion.

The only negative thing I can mention about this game is the fact that there are some abusable bugs out there, such as bugs which allows you to gather more supplies than intended. Other than that, I can't really find anything negative.

I really recommend this game to anyone out there who's looking for an interesting indie, society building, survival RPG-game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Survivalist is an open world, survival RPG where you play as Joe Wheeler, a self-centered businessman who has built a bunker just before the apocalypse with resources sufficient for one year, lived in his bunker during the apocalypse without any connection with the outer world, and finally decided to go out into the wasteland when he got out of resources. He doesn't have the slightest idea about the events happened after the apocalypse, unfamiliar with the surroundings, people and of course zombies.

Skip to the end for TL;DR
I will start with pointing the best thing about this game: the atmosphere. The feeling of isolation, chaos and depression, which are the outcomes of apocalypse are perfectly reflected. There will be times when you will have tough chocies, times you have to decide between two parties and you can't simply pick the 'evil' out of the sides, as moral values/ethics are simply not valid anymore; in a world where looting is the only way to survive, killing a person is justified by a simple conflict of interest and overall, being strong is the ultimate goal of everyone.

As humanity has taken a step back from the civilization, there are no laws and no enforcers. People have done what they had to do, in order to increase their chances to survive, they have gathered and started forming groups. There are small civilized settlements which started raising their own crops, outlanders, bandits, looters and all sorts of groups in game.  Now with such a case, a logical human being would find a decent community that shares his/her interests and join them. But Joe Wheeler happens to have a better idea; without knowing absolutely no one in this world and having nothing to offer, he will start building his own settlement.

This is the goal of this game. To make Joe Wheeler lead the biggest/strongest settlement in the area (i.e. feed his ego). Other than the first two characters who join you within the progress of storyline, people are not willing to leave their current, steady systems and join your newly-founded formation. And neither they are going to do it for the sake of your baby face and well-tailored businessman suit. You have to convince them. People have flexible opinions about you and to make them join your group, you have to act accordingly.  You can either complete their quests, protect them from raids and deal with someone they dislike to make them respect you, or pick the correct approach with your dialogues and bribe them with rare trinkets (e.g. chocolates, wine, books etc.) to make them like you. Only then, you can have enough influence on them to make them join your group.

Map is huge. And it is not empty at all. I need to say that I am really surprised with finding so much content here, as there are various events/characters/loot all around the map and this encourages discovering. Even when it gets really hard with lots zombies around, you know that you'll find something significant in that area and it definitely makes up to your effort.

Story progression is in a way that teaches you the mechanics of the game, which is appropriate as the game has so many things to do and you need to get to the end step-by-step. You also get to recruit people, explore the world and have better equipment with side quests, alongside with getting in the middle of conflicts between the factions and overall the intriguing plot.

According to your play style, game almost always allows you to choose between a diplomatic and a violent approach. Every choice you make show it's unique consequence in story progression. While you may find it more beneficial to rock the boat and loot loads of corpses for items, recruiting people instead of killing them makes your group bigger and thus, increases your chance to survive.

The game has a simple, strategy-game style of base building system. You need to have tools, materials and builders for building. You build houses, barns and wells for the needs of your group; and walls, watchtowers and pillboxes for the protection of your settlement. Protection around the settlement has to be set strategically, as there will be numerous zombie/rebel raids against your settlement and they get more frequent with the increasing population. The game sets a great balance for protection issues. If you assume that you will be perfectly safe after building wooden walls around your settlement, I am afraid you will soon find out how long it takes for a molotov coctail to burn down wood.

Protection is not the only issue. You need resources for your group. While you can usually find plenty of water around, food is not that easy to come by and you will quickly run out at some point. The game introduces another asset here: farming. This is also well implemented; you manage to feed your group with the food you scavenge around until the time you have access to crops/farming and after that, all you need to do is tasking some members of your group with farming and wait.  With more population, the amount of crops you have to plant also increases.

I believe these are enough for convincing people this game is amazing in terms of its RPG and sandbox factors.

Shooting mechanics are not hard if you follow some simple rules: stand still, aim and wait for the crosshair, shoot. Spraying is only a waste of bullets. The more you use weapons, you earn experience and get your firearms level up, this allows you to use more weapons and makes you shoot more effectively.

Sound effects and graphics are quite good for an indie game; I haven't had any staggers or graphical glitches despite the huge map with various interactive elements.

The only negative I could think of would be the controls. They are kind of way-out and this may make the game seem tedious first, however I got used to them in my first two hours and understood the way things work, so it's not really a big issue if you are interested in playing the game.

TL;DR
I am simply amazed by the content I got from this game. Really well-made and fascinating in many aspects. Brilliant as a RPG, a survival, a sandbox and in the end, for this price, this game is a steal. Kudos to the developers for getting it right with their first game. I can't recommend this enough.

reviewText:
Blog Review: http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2015/05/pc-game-review-survivalist.html

What Survivalist did Right


Nice building system
a cool feature in Survivalist is the building. you can build fences and razor wire to protect your chosen home base, protecting you from zombie hordes and raiders. you build houses for your followers and fellow survivors. you can build bunkers to give you an edge when fighting gun wielding hostiles. by the late game you'll have a nice little town.


Large open world to explore
something that Survivalist did right is its large open world for you to explore. you can also set up your base anywhere you want

Hostile Factions Attack events
the cities are the best places to find loot and food but going into them often will cause your base to be attacked by looters or zombie hordes. this adds some nice challenge to the game, it makes it dangerous to visit the cities a lot.



What Survivalist did Wrong

No real choices in dialogue
several times during the game you will be able to make dialogue “choices”. the only problem is that they really aren't choices.  you will get three ways to be a jerk without the choice to be  nice or understanding. or you will get three ways to be nice and understanding without a choice to be a jerk.


Zombies are way too fast
Zombies in Survivalist run as fast, if not faster than a speeding car. im not  joking. when you see a zombie it will be on top of you in 1 to 2 seconds.

Worst shooting system in a game ever
shooting in Survivalist is horrible. really horrible. if shooting worked this way in real life armies would be still be using swords. when you aim at a zombie or hostile NPC you have to wait about 5 to 10 seconds to even have a chance of hitting them. and if you or they move your “aiming” resets completely. and with the zombies being so fast it makes it impossible to wait to aim. also hostile NPCs seem to have pin-point accuracy hitting you virtually every shot.

Way too fast Day/Night system
Survivalist has a Day/Night system. during night your view is even more limited and more zombies are racing about. the problem is that the day is about six minutes.

you and all your friends are weaklings
this makes sense for you. i mean you’re a hedge fund manager. but why is every friendly person a weak shell of a human being? by that i mean that they will run out of stamina after just a few seconds of running. or they can only hold a few things of food before running out of storage space.

Annoyingly unhelpful Tutorial
In Survivalist they have kind of “learn as you go” tutorial. you play in the game world while they teach you want to do. the problem is it doesn't work. as i was leaving my bunker for the first mission i got hurt and needed to heal. but because they had to tell me how to open my inventory i couldn't. they didn't give me the pop-up message on how to open inventory until i got to a certain place. the problem with that is that there are two very strong zombies  in the way between me and that place, and with my person slowed even more by the wound i already had i could barely get past them.

Bad inventory system
another annoying thing in Survivalist is the fact that you can’t not drop things. you can only destroy them. also you can not select how much you want to destroy, you can only destroy the whole stack. this was really annoying to me as during my play through i had too much stuff and had already gotten ridden of all the junk out of my pack. i had a 50X stack of gold and if i dropped 10 i would be good. but i couldn't so i had to lose my 50 pieces of gold.

Bad graphics
I know I know, graphics aren't everything. but Survivalist looks worse than a PS2 game. everything is jagged and blurry.


Final Thoughts
Survivalist is by no means the best RPG zombie game out there, but it isn't the worst. if you really like RPGs and/or zombie games you should try Survivalist. and if you hate it you've only lost 5 bucks.

reviewText:
I'm coming up to my first hour in this game, and I can make the early insinuation that it is going to be a hit.

Admittedly, not for everybody. This post-apocalyptic zombie arcade game offers more than you'd actually of expected. I feel like I've made at least a £10 under-payment. There is so much content just wedged in to such an un-renown, outlandish game.

It lacks polish in the combat, and sometimes it can throw an abundance of haste zombies at you- which can be rather profuse, and irritating. The RPG elements to this game are fantastic, and I've really found myself getting drawn in to Joe Wheeler's character. If you have somebody in your group which is diabetic, you need insulin; if somebody in your group has been bitten, you need to inject yourself with some toxin, which has to be the parallel colour of the zombie's eyes who bit you. There's also a Sims-like command system which works spectacularly.

I'm just getting to a part where you can fortify your base- yes, you build and fortify your own base too. Another feature which isn't intricate, and easy to pick up.

For £3.99 you can NOT go wrong with Survivalist.
I'm looking forward to my future endeavours.
Well done developers for making a zombie game which isn't overhyped, and doesn't suck.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Despite the simplicity of the game mechanics in Survivalist, I found myself loving every second of playing this. It was fairly unique for a zombie game to actually feature infection as a mechanic rather than a plot point, as well as the antidotes for different strains. It's incredibly helpful that you can actually manage the community and assign tasks to survivors, such as lugging cement from a gas station down the road to the bunker until it's all secured in your base.\n\nI think that my only complaint at all about the game has nothing to do with the actual game, but rather that I wish that there was dlc or that the game was workshop enabled. The map itself is huge, but I feel that through either of these the game would receive an entirely new life.

Cons

Other

reviewText:
I sold a bullet proof vest for a backpack to carry more.
But I could only afford the Fuzzy wuzzy pink rabbit backpack....
10/10 would never speak of this again

in seriousness its a strangely addictive top down survival - do quests build a base - I love the ability to set up friendlys to forage and do looting automatically using all the chars in my team not just the ones in my party - for 5$ its a must have for sandbox/survival fans - quests include getting anti zombie drugs or a steady supply of insulen for your type 1 diabetic follower - balance out food ammo water and carry weights to make it pretty challenging - better then some 60$ games I've played

reviewText: Despite the simplicity of the game mechanics in Survivalist, I found myself loving every second of playing this. It was fairly unique for a zombie game to actually feature infection as a mechanic rather than a plot point, as well as the antidotes for different strains. It's incredibly helpful that you can actually manage the community and assign tasks to survivors, such as lugging cement from a gas station down the road to the bunker until it's all secured in your base.\n\nI think that my only complaint at all about the game has nothing to do with the actual game, but rather that I wish that there was dlc or that the game was workshop enabled. The map itself is huge, but I feel that through either of these the game would receive an entirely new life.

This is an incredible game.   I like the character interactions and the overall feel of the world after the apocalypse.

reviewText: I got this game for 3 Euro during it's most recent sale and I'm glad I did. It's a really fun, open world game that feels quite unique compared to a lot of zombie games I've previously played.\nThere are plenty of quests to keep you busy and you will also need to build defences at your base to keep looters and undead hordes away. Switching and controlling different characters is fairly straight forward and allows you to multi task with the members of your group with ease. Sometimes leaving group members to do tasks you've given them can get put off due to the character deciding he/she needs to find food/water first before continuing their task even when they're not overly hungry or thirsty. However, I think it's fair to say that this is the biggest problem I have with the game which isn't much of a problem, just a nuisance from time to time. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a simulation zombie game to put a decent amount of time into. To anyone who is interested in the game but not entirely sure on whether to buy the game or not, be sure to try the demo. It's what made my mind up

reviewText:
Survivalist is a great game. The thing I like about it most is the fact that you can control an entire community of people. The trailor didn't necessarily do a good job of showing community so I will talk about that and then tell you some Pros and Cons of the game(there are way more Pros).
In the community you have to provide for each and every need that all your survivors have. You need to provide them with water, food, ammo, sleep,insulin (for Alice a person with type 1 Diabetes) and protection. You can farm crops or scavenge nearby towns for food. For water you can make wells or scavenge. For ammo you have to scavenge gun shops. And for sleep you need to make sure you have enough buildings constructed or taken over that provide your members with sleep. Each member has a certain amount of respect and approval for you and if you fail to provide them with these necesseties they will lose approval and respect. There are two ways to recruit people to join you. You can help them and make them like you and they might join, or you can force them to join you by having fun with a bullet and rifle. You can tell your people to be guards, farmers, build things, follow you and help you, medics, scavengers you can even set up a team to explore. These are just the first parts of owning a community but I hope it helped.
Here are the Pros and Cons
Pros
You can control your characters directly or in a control mode
You can control each character
There is a huge variety in skills and a really cool skill system
The game slowly gets harder and harder as you progress
The game has a cool zombie system with different strains that are harder
The game periodically sends hordes or groups of zombies and looters to attack your base
I love the missions in the game
Good online gameplay except for one thing(see Cons)

Cons
Graphics aren't the best
Sometimes glitches will happen when forcing someone to join your community
In multiplayer if you get in a big fight against zombies the game will sometimes lag


overall I believe survivalist is a very clever and cool game and I really hope this review helped.

reviewText:
What a lovely little gem. I almost feel guilty for buying it at such a low price. I was very pleasantly surprised to learn just how fun and... honestly kind of complex this game is.

PROS:

* Great gameplay. Combat can feel a bit repetitive, but being able to cap a zombie in the leg to prevent the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from jumping you is pretty good. I also really like the skill progression, though it can feel like a grind at times. There's homesteading, zombie shooting, looter shooting, quest taking, micro-management somewhat akin to RTS games, building a huge posse of fellow survivors, exploration... lots of content in this game.

* Content. I'm still kind of baffled just how rich this game is for its price tag. 30 hours in and I still am not done with my first playthrough. I'd say that's pretty impressive. Along the same lines, the RPG elements are pretty solid. I was amused to see that characters respond to just about anything you do to them or others in their community. If you so desired, you could just wiped everyone out with extreme prejudice, or you could be more of a peacemaker and try to recruit as many people as you can... including bandits. I'm somewhere in between. People even remember you being RUDE to them.


*Game design. The author of this game clearly went to great lengths to implement depth and replayability. There are three game winning scenarios that the player can choose from, people to save or not save, quests to take or not take, and just the fact that you can't please everyone in the game makes it so that you can easily boot it back up and try a different path.



-----

CONS:


Honestly... I can't think of many serious problems with this game other than a few minor nitpicks, but there are two things that bother me in particular-


* Ear-bleeding music. UGH. The soundtrack in this game is just hideous. I've played most of it with it muted. It's a minor gripe, I suppose, but still.

*The allied AI can sometimes be a bit bone-headed... like they may wander away from the path of safety just to make a shortcut (and bumping into zombies and looters along the way), they waste time sometimes by wandering around FOREVER looking for food or water when they could just complete their ♥♥♥♥ing jobs and go back to base to eat and drink.


----


All in all, VERY solid game. I highly recommend it. The price tag certainly helps me say that it's worth every penny.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After putting in more than 60hrs (at time of writing), I must say that I really enjoy this game.

============================
Good points:
Ability to build up areas to fortify as a base against the zombie / looter hordes

While there is a main quest, there are also plenty of side quests that aid your survival

Abilty to recruit in-game characters to join your community

Controls are simple to pick up, learning curve not steep. To perfect the game though, you will find that you'll be challenged sufficiently

Great game community who discuss topics and provides assistance quickly in the Forums

Clearing the Fog of War can be incredibly satisfying

There are plenty of moral decisions to be made, and choices have consequences. It's a breath of fresh air to have more sensible and realistic options.

It's a one-man development team!
Bad points:
Zombies are INCREDIBLY fast. One moment I'm walking and clearing the fog, the next moment I'm on the floor and trying desperately to press the spacebar to kick the zombie off before I get bitten. After a while you get used to it though. They make plenty of sounds so you will tend to be a bit more alert when you know you're around one============================

It really is a good game, and I recommend it to anyone who likes apocalypse games mixed with RTS and building up bases. I mean, it's just $5. What can go wrong? Just one day without dinner?

reviewText:
If you like the survival/zombie genre then this game is a must buy! Fantastic game, with individual character development, tons of potential NPC allies and enemies, expansive map to explore, good story, etc. It goes on sale for a mere couple of bucks, often, which is really just stealing money from the folks who deserve more for a really well made game. If you are on the fence, then spend the few bucks to pick this up; you'll probably be surprised you hadn't discovered it sooner!

Pros:
+Interesting/original spin on the zombie outbreak scenario. Fast zombies suck but are awesome.
+Lots of NPCS hidden around the desert, mostly in small enclaves to interact with. Hostile humans can often be turned around to become neutral, or even join your group, if you play your cards right.
+Base building is balanced; the buildings and upgrades give benefits comparable to the work required to construct them.
+Finite, if generous, quantities of building materials rewards careful selection for base location and smart construction of buildings.
+Anyone who gets taken by an infected becomes an infected; you'll find former friends and enemies have become the very zombies that are now attacking you!
+Individual character development, with uncomplicated stats and skills.
+World changes as you play; NPC enclaves will eventually succumb to wandering bands of bandits and zombies, including side-quest locations and even groups of hostile survivors end up perishing over time.
+Reasonable graphics, the game has very modest system requirements.
+Good replay value; it is quite a long game and can be played through several times.

A real nice touch is that the NPC's appear to have the same rules as the player characters; everyone needs food, water, and sleep. If the NPC's that do the farming of an enclave or group die then the other members will start travelling the desert in search of provisions. It also usually leads to the death of everyone else in that group as their members individually run zombies they can't handle. Then they become zombies and help polish off the next desperate survivor who leaves the camp in search of food. The bandit groups might be an exception to this, hostile survivors that cannot be negotiated with, seem to never move and have no resources close by to sustain them. They stay awake for months at a time, with no food or water, the true zombies of the apocalypse!

Cons:
-Character development, while effective, is quite simple. It may be part of the charm but it feels like some lost potential.
-Base building can be pretty tedious when trying to gather resources from remote locations. Your runners either constantly run to the point of exhaustion(extremely vulnerable to zombies!!!) or walk about at a casual pace.
-Unable to create groups of runners for salvaging/gathering. Having to select each individual survivor and send them out to collect resources is a nuisance. These survivors all function separately, instead of working as team, out in the field. Lots of times a survivor gets mauled by a couple of zombies that they've encountered while one or two other survivors, also travelling to the same destination, are within a screen's distance and do not go to the aid of their fellow survivor. The only work around I found was to assign guards to each runner, which works, but wastes a lot of carrying potential.
-As above, you have to micromanage your survivors out in the field. Lone survivors are no match for two or more zombies at a time. Even teams of two, with a dedicated guard, tend to get overwhelmed pretty easily. It wouldn't be much of problem except they tend to be much less effective when AI controlled so you have to be quite vigilant. If your main group is also dealing with an encounter, it is very easy to miss a runner in trouble.

This is a great game and would easily be worth $20-$25, especially to fans of the genre! I've stayed up far later than I should on many a weekday to just get a bit more Survivalist" time in!"

reviewText:
Better Bang for your Buck than Fallout 4:

More Realistic Survival Scenarios: Your character must constantly satisfy hunger and thirst, as well as constantly fend off hostile survivors and zombies.  Wounds require bandaging quickly, or you'll bleed to death.  A bite from a zombie requires a speedy shot of antigen, which often isn't available (making a zombie bite the death sentence it ought to be).  Choosing the right balance of equipment with weight limitations is a constant challenge.

Better Moral Dilemmas: Would you be willing to murder a doctor or a random survivor to steal insulin for a member of your party? Do you have time to work odd jobs to make the gold to buy a shot of insulin to make her last a few more days? Can you accept a survivor into your party knowing that he is an outlaw in a town you frequent?

Multiplayer: Unlike Fallout 4, there is actually a multiplayer mode in this game.  Like Destiny, the multiplayer co-operative  is meant to blend seamlessly into the singleplayer experience.  Unlike Destiny, Survivalist properly executes on this feature.  The chat log is extremely handy.

You can't go wrong with this game at full prce, or on sale, buy it now!!

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=imVU1WHAgOU

The written review is way too long and can't post the whole review here, so you have to watch my video for complete information about the game

Are you getting tired from games with zombies? Yes? Well, i'm certainly not. This game have zombies and it's a top-down shooter with light crafting and strategy to spice things up.

The game takes place in the near future, one year after the collapse of civilization. You take the role of John Wheeler, a wealthy L.A. manager, who own a underground bunker in the middle of the desert, filled with food and water for 1 year, in which you took refuge. On the 364 day in he picked up signal for help on his radio, coming from somewhere near by. He goes out to investigate . You find woman named Alice locked, you help her and the rest is up to you to find out. Half way through the game story picks up and starts to get interesting and it have few twists.

Usually in a game like this, the is goal to find out, where the disease started, find a cure or save someone. Here it's not like that. Your first priority is surviving. Some quests will lead to answers. To reach the end of the game, you have complete five objectives: construct certain number and type of buildings, enough food for feeding your people, neutralize all regional treats, find love, have at least one person in your community with max skill level in each of: Fitness, Firearms, Construction, Farming and Medicine.

The game was first introduce for Xbox Live before landing on the PC platform and it's almost perfect port. The most disappointing thing are the video options. Only fullscreen, resolution and large fonts. Textures are okay, movement of everyone is kind of robotic. All human and zombie characters differ from each other only by the clothes and skin color. In Sound there are only 3 options – sound effects, menu sound and music. But all those things are minor problems, the game is indie and it's awesome!

However, the developer did make mouse and keybord controls perfect. So many variations in Controls menu. I was really surprised by this. And of course all keys can be rebind. You can even play with a controller if you like.

Next is gameplay. Here is where the game shines a lot. I'll start with the base. After rescuing Alice, you find out she have diabetes and she need constant supply of insulin. Through the hole game you will either have to buy it or searching for abandoned pharmacies. You and Alice are heading to the nearest town and there Isham, another survivor, will join you and decide John's bunker will be your base. Here you will find the strategy part and it's giving orders to your people. And what are they? To bring supplies to your base and build. So, Isham is constructs, Alice is carrying and you complete quests. In the beginning you can only build shack outhouse, wooden and wire fences, gates and wooden watch tower. After gaining few levels in Construction it will unlock more things – barn, well, concrete tower and pillbox. All buildings will improve the life of your people. Don't make wrong conclusions. For the most part this is  action oriented game, with nice story and it's not another with only crafting and surviving.

The game wants from you to build certain number and type of buildings. That way you will have places for everyone and everything. More people you have, more buildings you need. They are used to store supplies and for people to sleep. Of course, you need to defende your base. That's way you have watch towers and pillboxes. When someone is inside them, it's more hard to shoot them.

One extremely important elemnt of the game is feeding your community and supplying them with water. In the first few hours they will eat cans and chips and water you can be found in dead bodies, buildings and water towers. But there is easier way for providing  both of them. After the mentioned hours, you can plant crops. This way you will have constant supply of food. And if you don't want to search for water, build a well. It's also used for watering the crops.

You can take control of every single person in your community and make them do what the game allows you to do. I was quite surprised by the AI. When you give an order, there is no need to babysit them. When someone is thirsty or hungry, he goes where you store food and water. If don't have them in your base, he/she is searching for you. If he wants to sleep, he goes to a building alone and after it's done, continues his task from where he stoped . Builder don't have enough materials? He goes to the nearest dicovered place to get them. Sometimes suppliers encounter 1 or 2 zombies and they deal with them without a problem. You don't need to take control over them, unless they are big group. If this is the case – you better rum. I didn't rely entirly on the AI and you don't have to. While people sleep, I feed them and give them water and supplies. Sometimes I take control if something attack them. Simple, but effective.

Every single person have 5 skills to develop: Fitness, Firearms, Constuction, Farming and Medicine. Level 5 is the top, but not all characters can, they are just limited. Only when using certain skill, you gain experience for it. For example – using a weapon will increase Firearms. There is artificial way for gaining levels. You will find books for the respective skill and the only requirement is to carry them all the time.

On the right side is shown the person you control, mini map (there is big map also), what weapon he uses, does he have bulletproof vest and fatigue. If you run for too long, the character is getting tired and you better stop on one place or just walk, because if you run it to a zombie or looter, it will be hard to fight them.

There are few stats, that you need to keep an eyeon them. They are hunger, thirts, for smokers lung cancer, for Alice glucose level. When you walking or running without a break, people don't eat or drink water, so keep in mind to stop for e brief moment.

If you want to get somewhere quickly or people sleep and you don't have anything to do, speed up the game. But there is a risk. When you are in this mode and you control someone and zombie attack the character, you may not push it on time and this have consequences.

The map is huge and dangerous, but there are friendly communities. From them you will get quests. Most of them are just killing looters. All communities have traders. From them you can buy a lot of stuff or sell. The currency here is gold. You will get it from searching buildings, cars, bodies and completing quests. The first thing you need to buy is backpack. It will let you carry more stuf with you. The bigger backpack and higher level of Fitness will allow to take more things with you.

You have total of 6 weapons – pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper, RPG and Molotov. The shooting is as follows: you hold the right mouse button to lock-on target. For more accurate shots you have to stay in one place for the crosshair to turn red. But if you are not moving, you are sitting duck. Bigger the Firearms level, fastert the crosshair turns red. It's fun to shoot with every weapon. They don't have recoil, but even if you have highest level of Firearms, doesn't guarantee every single shot to hit the target. Don't expect to get RPG right from the beginning. You will start with pistol. For him it's easy to find ammo, but it gets progressively harder to find for the better weapons. While the target is lock-on, you can choose with the mouse to shoot it in the legs, torso or head. They have their advantages and disadvantages. The head is harder to be hit, but guarantees quick kill. The torso is easy to hit, but you do less damage. Shooting the legs leads zombies to limp and generally slow them down.

reviewText:
The bad graphics are misleading since Survivalist plays really smoothly, as a modern game should. It was extremely addictive.

This is actually a really cool game. It's a lot better than most of the zombie sims I've tried. It has interesting characters, an actual plot, and intriguing gameplay.

The only things I would like to add to this game is

- A better overview for my survivors, like a map view with all of my survivors where I can set where and how they should work

- More emphasis on base defense - I'd like more defensive structures and more attacks on my base.

reviewText:
Survivalist is another survival horror featuring zombies, yet not completely generic.
It's a top down shooter with some RPG elements like individual survivor's stats and inventory/party management.
You do quest for both the main story and sidestories (which are mostly for the sake of continuing the main story).
You can command survivors that you recruited in your community to either scavenge for supplies, defend your base, improve it, or help you by joining your party.
You have some needs to take care of like thirst, hunger and sleep and if you or a party member get bitten he will become meds dependant and will need costant medical supplies or he will turn, if it's a main character it will results in a game over.
The combat is either punch zombies to death which takes forever or use a gun, the latter have more precision depending on both the distance and how long do you aim at your target.
The performance of the game are quite good but it lacks in the options departement, in the graphic options there is only resolution and an option that if turned on it will change the frame limiter from 30 to 60.
For the first hour the game seems like a fun and innovative survival game but sadly it isn't.
The gameplay becomes repetitive fast along with the quests, the story is boring and the  characters are easily forgotten.

and discouraged me from playing any further.


Overall Score I would give: 5/10"

reviewText:
Despite the premise which I always find enjoyable and the clever little character quips this game suffers from two major issues.

First off the interface is rather anti-intuitive. The controls feel like they were mapped by a three armed man with Parkinsons. Secondly, Looting and combat feel more like a chore than an enjoyable game experience...thanks again mostly to the lack of thought put into the interface.

For $4 it isn't bad but I just can't stand behind this title yet. Very rough. Couldn't even get past the first half hour playing it.

reviewText:
For all the praise this game gets it has some glaring problems.

The controls are very counter intuitive and will also cause you to mis-click many things since far to much is done with the same button.

The same button you use to fire does almost everything else inscluding reloading a game when you don't even want to. Oddly the buttong you use to kick can cause the same problem.

The quests will often beeline you into choices you never wanted to make. Such as trying to play as good person and being forced to be greedy for gold.

The crafting and inventory lacks any depth at all, with crafting being basically an abandoned concept.

Playing it is constantly frustrating and all of its good points have glaring problems.

I honestly don't think there is one positive feature about this game that doesn't come with an annoying downside. Unless you count being cheap.

Don't buy the game until the developer learns how to make it accesible at least. It gets lots of praise due to potential only not actual delivery.

reviewText: This game would seem interesting if you read about it. Unfortunately, the controls and interface are non-intuitive in the extreme. The player wanders about with no sense of direction or purpose, and has little interaction with the world around him. Enemies overtake you in an unpredictable manner, and you must aim" at them on the one hand
date: and then "attack" them using an altogether separate control system. I'd really enjoy a game like this if it were fun
recommended: but I'd recommend better-designed "post-apocalyptic" games. Not to specifically "plug" a game
hoursPlayed: but a hint as to the name would be "the resulting devastation after nuclear war that has an amazing half-life." Another hint is that you're raised in a vault safely underground and leave to see what the outside world looks like. Even if this game were on a terrific sale
voteText: steer clear of it. In good conscience I cannot recommend this game."

reviewText: Being honest here, I think this game is complete trash. Maybe it's not my type and i've hardly played it, but I started to realize it's pretty unfinished and probably won't be super good until it becomes fully complete. First of all, the aiming is very weird. I don't really like the system. Having most zombies run at you I guess is realistic but you really can't tell when they will jump out and kill you. Why I got bored so fast is I found my self running from zombies, they were too fast and I couldn't really see them coming that well. Fatique left me defenceless after one zombie jumped on me and I had to push him off and I would enter a house only to literally be camped by these zombies. They would wait out my door and murder me as soon as I came out.\nMaybe it's not my type but I feel like this game is just very incomplete. I've hardly gotten into it so maybe I oughta give it another shot. But for now, i'll leave this review negative. Not reccomended for anyone really unless your an extreme zombie diehard fan.

reviewText: Damn...I just cannot handle games that aren't balanced and this zombie" game just doesn't feel right. Im sure a lot of people will enjoy this game and I can't pretend it isn't priced right
date: but...... I think the devs need to learn a little more about the zombie world before their next attempt. I'm really not sure what they were thinking trying to combine a "state of decay" like game with infected zombies running at you from the dark fog in packs of 12 at 100mph when your sight range is about 25ft. You spend most of your time just trying to side step their massive jump lunges and kicking them off one after another when they do get you. It quite literally gets to the point of annoyance and repetitiveness so quickly
recommended: that I pretty much shut it off an hr in. I mean in what "fast moving zombie" movie like "28days" or "World War Z" do you see people carelessly just strolling down to the local store to collect chicken wire one piece at a time with the delusional goal of eventually building a fence that will stop this type of zombies. I mean come on....all zombie fans know the difference between the slow zombies and the fast zombies
hoursPlayed: along with how different survival tactics would be...well

reviewText: Being honest here, I think this game is complete trash. Maybe it's not my type and i've hardly played it, but I started to realize it's pretty unfinished and probably won't be super good until it becomes fully complete. First of all, the aiming is very weird. I don't really like the system. Having most zombies run at you I guess is realistic but you really can't tell when they will jump out and kill you. Why I got bored so fast is I found my self running from zombies, they were too fast and I couldn't really see them coming that well. Fatique left me defenceless after one zombie jumped on me and I had to push him off and I would enter a house only to literally be camped by these zombies. They would wait out my door and murder me as soon as I came out.\nMaybe it's not my type but I feel like this game is just very incomplete. I've hardly gotten into it so maybe I oughta give it another shot. But for now, i'll leave this review negative. Not reccomended for anyone really unless your an extreme zombie diehard fan.

reviewText:
The game will not start for me. Here is the error log:
Application: Survivalist.exe
Framework Version: v4.0.30319
Description: The process was terminated due to an unhandled exception.
Exception Info: System.IO.FileNotFoundException
at ZombieApocalypse.Program.Main(System.String[])

I have tried uninstalling and reinstalling to no avail.

This error is no longer occuring after I tried the solution provided by the Dev and a few other solutions. Now this one is:

Application: Survivalist.exe
Framework Version: v4.0.30319
Description: The process was terminated due to an unhandled exception.
Exception Info: System.BadImageFormatException
at ZombieApocalypse.Program.Main(System.String[])

im running .net framework 4.6.1 if that matters

Here is an update to this review. After fixing the issue (The developer was awesome in helping with this). I started off playing coop. It was a great time with my wife who decided to micromanage my community. I absolutely love the possibilities here in this game. You can be a lone gun and only play for yourself (no time limits or urgencies except for the beginning) or you can build a huge community and deal with everyone's problems (pretty realistic). If you enjoy micromaging things than this is your game. If you enjoy scary post apocalyptic settings than this is your game.

In all honesty I have played the big box" games that cost $60 on release and none of them compare to this game which is still being developed. The story behind any of the paths you choose is astounding for a choose your own adventure sort of game. Survivalist really hit the nail on the head.

10/10 would blow up felipe's house with a rocket launcher again.

10/10 would run my 60 member community into the enemy base with just pistols and molotovs.

3/10 would want to meet a diabetic in the real world apocolypse"

reviewText:
I can appreciate that this game is still in early development, but from what I see ...
This game is azz:

Horribly bad, outdated graphics (looks like Grand Theft Auto 1) and animations
The music is cheesy and doesn't fit the mood in any way -- you'll instantly turn down your speakers
The Fog of War makes light-speed zombies practically impossible to dodge or hit -- Apparently people can't see farther that 5ft in front of them, in a desert, in sunlight, in the apocalypse.
The targeting system is virtually broken -- trying to aim at legs, torso and head is impossible by moving the mouse up and down ... when you have to move the mouse around to even pick a target.
Of course, your AI teamates are stupid as all hell -- while they are John Rambos while traveling with you, good luck having them rest up and heal in the bunker while you make a supply run.  You'll be halfway through the run when the party memeber decides to disregard your orders, exit the bunker into a mob of zombies while unarmed and estentially getting eaten, thus ending your game.
The savegame function is a joke:  Hey, your party memeber just committed suicide ... np quickload .... whoops ... the autosave dinged, literally, right as the partymemeber enters the middle of the mob.  At least you can watch her/him get eaten over and over and over ....
Horrible, un-wieldly dialouge, inventory and command menus.  Just ... ridiculous.

There's about 20 other reasons why this game sucks.  I can appreciate an indie game like this, especially for $5 ... but it's just horrible.

Fun idea; terrible execution.  Just give me your $5 and save yourself the hassle of this game.

reviewText:
I cannot actually remember when I bought this game. I played it at last because... it updated.

Top-down combat that's not very good. You can't see zombies before they're running at you. Your companions get to do gun combat. YOU get to lie under a zombie and kick it off. Since you have to shoot things to get better at shooting things...

I was hoping, from the other reviews, that there was some reason to keep playing. But action combat with RPG stats in this case is purely translating to you are bad at this
date: and it's the part of the game that isn't walking". And I thought

reviewText:
I do not recommand this game for anyone that doesnt have all day to play this game.
First of all, graphics are terrible to have this game come out in 2015.
Second, when you shoot zombies in this game you miss 50% of the time, so when the zombie if is your face, you miss like by 5 meters.
Third, the walking to different parts of this map takes a long long time! A quest/mission need you to travel to several places and it takes a hella long time just to walk your character over there.
Fourth, your backpack literally has no room! You can barely pack anything in your pack, after you pack things like ammo, gun badage, some food, water. You are pretty much full in your backpack and you have to throw things away for loots you find.
Fifth, the directions of the quests in this game is extremely ♥♥♥♥ing confusing! I don't know if it is just me, but the directions are very unclear and hard to follow. Sometimes glitch happens and you don't get missions done or your mission SOMEHOW disappear.
Sixth, you might think it is fun to build a fortress to defend against zombie, yeah that it fun BUT IT TAKES ♥♥♥♥ING YEARS TO BUILD ONE. You have to get supplies and transfer supplies to your base, with a backpack and toolbox so that takes ♥♥♥♥ing years and your backpack
I do not recommand this game, i would 10/10 refund this game. This game was fun in the beginning but because of how confusing it was and how long it takes to do stuff is just boring,

reviewText:
I like most of the concept except the need to sleep. If all characters are deprived of sleep, then all of them needs sleep. If this happens I don't really know what to do but wait.

There are quests around when talking to NPCs but I think the map is so huge, I autowalk a lot. The fact that there are lots of empty spaces that makes walking boring.

reviewText:
Very good simulation game. It's very hard as it should be. The hordes are very dangerous because it's big risk to get infected. In game you can recruit other survivors, build, trade, scavenge and ect. This game is very interesting and hard.

EDIT:
After i played it longer i saw more interesting things. There are lots of factions and you can recruit all people in the game. But one thing i miss. There are is very poor crafting system, no forging, tree cutting, mining, and there are not too many different weapons : Pistol, shotgun,Smg,Sniper,molotov,and i think RPG.( haven't seen Rpg yet)

And you know what? I really missed Ai(people) faction wars, they just stand in their bases and only farmers growing crops and thats it. By the way only corns? I dont want to eat in post apocalyptic world only corns. I want potatoes, apples, bananas, grains, carrots and ect.

Edited: Thats why from 10 i give only 7.
7/10 (and the game still needs co-op)


+ One more thing after i almost completed the game... This game has very cool story line.

reviewText:
The game is cute, definately soemthing worth playing.
Combat system pretty much sucks, the UI is clunky but looks nice, there's no interiors for the buildings and you can't see very far.  Two hours was about as long as it took me to have seen enough to not be interested anymore.
The biggest thing i didn't like is that it's story driven, you're stuck with a diabetic so that drives your necessity for exploration on high, which means you can't just build your town and make it self sufficient before setting off into the dark, and going anywhere takes ages.

If this game was a procedurally generated world with the story as a tutorial then i'd definately be playing it instead of writing this.

reviewText:
This game is better than you would think after playing it for just a few hours. After a while, you begin to constantly adapt to the ever changing world that is Survivalist, making choices in power or money, life or love.

The story-line can be edited to many different outcomes in the mysterious choices of our three protagonists that could change as the tides turn. It could be five, ten maybe hundreds of characters that build the story of this game.

If you could just not see the negative reviews, they don't really make that much sense. Yes, the game will expand and take a bigger shape in zombie survival and it is much better than buying a hamburger with somem fries and drink for 5$.

Trust me, after a little, you will not regret the choice. And if its only because of the tragic downfalls in the story, then let me tell you, I know, it can get sad...

reviewText:
First Impressions:

After seeing this game for cheap and not on Early Access I thought I would pick it up. The game is pretty fun, with some nice mechanics. I love the little selfie type cam that shows what your player is doing.

I will keep playing but if you want to see how the first 20 minutes of play go check me out playing below.

reviewText:
Played for 12 minutes, asked for a refund.

I had high hopes for this game due to the positive recommendations and it was number 1 on my wishlist.  I thought they had mispriced the game as it appeared cheap for how good the reviews were.  Why I didn't enjoy the game and got this refunded:

- The graphics were not great.  I can usually get past not having top graphics but this was a tough one.  Not good graphics for characters or scenery.
- The controls were clunky for me. Too many keys, and requied use of mouse wheel when I'm on keyboard without a mouse.  You can reconfigure the keys, but there are a lot to reconfigure.
- The combat system seemed weak - hard to target, and very quick and rushed combat without much skill only a few key presses at right moment.
- A walker jumped at me at seemingly a few hundred miles an hour and not much I could do to react, especially with the clunky key pressing combat system.
- One little attack and you keep having to use a bandage.
- You pillage zombies to find ammo, guns and things?  They would really carry them?

Yes the games cheap, I hoped undeservedly so, but it's cheap for a reason.  I just couldn't get into this one, I find other good value games a lot more addictive.

reviewText:
Since people are complaining about thier inability to click a link(seriously?) I've decided to rewrtite as a pro/con bulletpoint system.

Pros:
Decent building system for your town

Cons-
Boring combat
Dry as a pretzel dialogue
Very binary rep system
Game degrades into an mmo style rep grind
AI is brainless and often infuriating
Sound design does nothing to build atmposphere and is counterproductive to the theme of the game
Video options are sorely lacking
Graphics and animations are exceptionally terrible

For a more indepth review, use the link below.

http://realgamerreviews.com/games/survivalist-review-thriller-if-it-was-terrible/

you can also find the video review on youtube below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sa7u3qsqaJw

Everything this game does has been done better elsewhere. Only buy if you are on some kind of extreme budget and REALLY like zombies.

reviewText: I was skeptical at first. I thought it would be some stupid childish game BUT I read all the other reviews and figured what the hell, for $6 im gonna give this game a shot. All I can say is, this is a good $6 well spent. Yeah the graphics arent much, but for the price they are good enough and actually the graphics really arent that bad, they could be worse. I may only have 6 hours on record but ive enjoyed every minute. There is ALWAYS something to do, the game keeps you busy whether its killing zombies and looters, building your own community, or going on mission after mission. Another thing that shocked me was how friggen HUGE the map is. Ive done alot of exploring in my 6 hrs of game time and Ive only scratched the surface of the map, WOW. In sum, this game is 110% worth the price, Im actually suprised its not more $$. Its better than some games Ive paid way more money for a whole lot less. You need to try this game, seriously.

reviewText:
What can I say about this game except its the best value ive ever gotten for my cash on steam.

first let me start off by saying the combat is very arcade like but it works.

the graphics are alittle dated but definitely work with the game.

the true power of this game comes from survivor management and the building aspect.
you want your survivors to survive because you actually feel like they are your survivors.
good game, great value for the price.

pros
fast gameplay
nice quests
feels like a survival  game should
ability to manage your survivors and leave them doing automated tasks.
ability to get infected and then the need to find cures.
the zombies are a very real threat.

cons
character animation such as running could look better.
arcade like combat system (although ive grown to really like it and it suits the game I put it down as a con because I know people will be turned off by the arcade combat before they even buy the game)

recommendations for improvements
ability to customise the main characters look.

score 7 out of 10

reviewText:
Survivalist proves that a game doesn't have to have fancy graphics or top-notch production values to be FUN.  Granted I'm still early in the game, but so far I've had a great time playing and would recommend to anyone who likes solo, action RPG type games.

PROS
+ Intuitive, responsive controls and menus
+ Interesting RPG elements and quests
+ Sandbox, village-building feel
+ Killing the infected is fun and challenging
+ Exploring and looting is a blast
+ Love my bunny backpack!

CONS
- Graphics may seem cruddy to some
- Character viewpoint is limited (needs better map system)
- Some systems are confusing (farming, assigning complex tasks)

reviewText:
This is legitemately one of the best games I have ever bought on steam...especially for being a $5 indie game. But that said, its still not going to be  a game that everyone enjoys. The game is more focused on community building than combat, theres several structures and defensive structures you can build....although i could see the game being ALOT better with more choices in the future. Alot of people hate on the graphics, but remember its a top down indie game.....and your only paying $5 for it. The combat can be a little repetitive....and lacking in weapons (aside from fist there is only like 6 weapons i think). But like i said its more focused on building a small community and recruiting survivors to join ur community. The game can get a lil fustrating having one of the main characters being a type 1 diabetic and CONSTANTLY needing insulin which often u have to complete some fetch and kill missions to get. But your free to off her, or send her off into the wilderness alone at any time u choose, and still be able to complete the game. You loose a lil bit of the story and background....but you can still do it. The game can have some wcked replayablity since you can build anywhere....start a war with any of the other communitys or make different choices on who you want to help / kill. All in all it has plenty of flaws but way worth the $5 price tag.


-Cons:
-Somewhat repetitive combat
-The feels you get when you off one of the main characters
-Feels slightly lacking in building options and weapons
-Horrendously repetitive music
-No multiplayer currently

-Pros:
-An excellent game for anyone who enjoys city builders
-Good replayabilty, if you enjoy the game at all
-Very Resonable price tag
-Runs extremely smoothly
-Very easy to learn the game
-Complete freedom to play / build wherever and however you want
-Random attacks by hordes of zombies, and gangs of looters keeps the game from being way to overly easy
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is deffinately worth the $5 price tag.  I have paid more for games that are much worse with less content.

The only thing that I would like to see change here is to have a low respawn rate in the areas that you have explored, or possibly some sort of zombie migration where zombies would migrate from outside the map into the cleared out areas.  I have noticed what seems to be an incidental zombie appearing once in a while in areas that I have cleared, but it is not enough to even make a slight challange.

Currently the only respawning that I have seen has been from the semi random events where zombie packs or looters detect your tracks in any town that you have explored.  This is a fairly nice feature but it is really too easy to deal with them under most situations.

Odd things:
Zombies can't break down wood walls or fences.
The green zombies are not a threat at all once you have upgraded your stats a couple of points.

My Easy Game:
I restarted my game a couple of times once I figured out how the game play worked and finally found my first sniper rifle.  First thing I did was to take my bare handed main char and hunt down the green zombies, working my way towards a location where I knew a fitness book was availible with only greens around.  By the time I went back to the totorial I had 2 stars in Fitness and 1 Fitness book which made me completely immune to greens and fairly good against blues.  I then went and grabbed both the secondary characters and grabbed the easiest sniper rifle and then finished the tutorial.

From there I would just use the Sniper rifle to explore and a shotgun to kill.  Anytime I had to take care of looters I would do head shots and one hit kill them from beyond their range.  The most problematic things so far in the game are Looters in towers which give them extra range, and white zombie hoards.

By the end of the first day I had 2-3 in both fitness and firearms for both the MC as well as the secondary Girl, while the third guy was used to act as the person who did construction.  I also pushed fitness for him as it was valuable for the few times that he went into combat as well as for increasing the carry capacity.

My current game has 9 characters with the map about half uncovered as well as all the main locations explored.  Additionally I have not once been bitten by a zombie so the antigen have not been of any value to me.  While the High end sniper ammo is not all that plentiful the shot gun and assult rifle is, not to mention about 70k of pistol ammo which is great for those you have manning towers.  This being the case the only one that carries a sniper rifle is my active character for when I am either exploring or when I am needing to take down looters.  If I could instruct my non active characters in combat behavior than I could see spreading out the sniper rifles.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Really worth it for $5 game, especially for Open-World game.

What I like is the surviving mechanics of course. Well there're three main aspects that you need to pay attention with to keep you alive, hunger, thirst, and sleep deprivation. There's an additional aspect for sickness. There're skills as well. You can level it up if you use its tool often. Also you can level it up by using magazine. What I liked is the skills' level will be down if you get shot but they will be recovered eventually. The combat is okay. I like the way you can aim the head, body, or legs individually based on your skill with your weapon.

I don't want to rate the story because it's not finish yet but what I dislike is the beginning of the story because it's ridiculous. Some people may notice that the girl can climb up the fence and save her sister, also why her sister brought the key? I dislike the UI, especially the font but it's pretty identical to indie game so it's quite okay. The animations for walking and sprinting are really weird.

I shocked by its musics. Totally different with the atmosphere of post-apocalyptic. But the musics make me enthusiastic.

Don't look at my gameplay stats because I played this game about 20 hours.

reviewText:
Survivalist proves that a game doesn't have to have fancy graphics or top-notch production values to be FUN.  Granted I'm still early in the game, but so far I've had a great time playing and would recommend to anyone who likes solo, action RPG type games.

PROS
+ Intuitive, responsive controls and menus
+ Interesting RPG elements and quests
+ Sandbox, village-building feel
+ Killing the infected is fun and challenging
+ Exploring and looting is a blast
+ Love my bunny backpack!

CONS
- Graphics may seem cruddy to some
- Character viewpoint is limited (needs better map system)
- Some systems are confusing (farming, assigning complex tasks)

reviewText:
Probably one of the best zombie apocalypse games I have played. The main thing i like about the game is the ability to set your people to different jobs, I don't know if there is a limit to the amount of people you can have at once but for now I have 4.

1 man is my lookout who basically stays in the watch tower for most of the day, another one is my scavenger who looks through abandoned houses and cars for anything useful like food or ammo, then my last 2 work in a team, one goes to collect wood to build my fences to keep out zombies or looters and the man with him is just their as fire power incase he runs in to trouble on his own.

I was searching the area with 3 of my people and came across an older couple who set up life on top of a small hill, the old man started to disrespect me so I killed him then asked his wife to join my community, she said no so I thought to myself I have no reason to keep her alive and killed her too. 10/10

You should definitely buy this game if you're in to strategy as the choices you make affect your story.

reviewText: I'm absolutely addicted to this game, which I must add was purchased for under $5!!!  Although not too customizable (except for backpacks and weapons), and you'll damn the day you promised to chase this desert non-stop for whatever limited quantities of insulin there are left for an individual who essentially is just a stranger to you, it all seems to fall into the right places.  The insulin chase adds the element of urgency to the whole thing, otherwise you'd turn this experience into a city builder sim.  Scraping by, and fighting tooth and nail to survive, is your humble beginning.  Leading a tactical squad later on in the game is when it really pays off.  Really wish there were armor options aside from bullet proof vests, both for armor and cosmetics.  Oh well, no big deal really.  Great game, great price, great entertainment.

reviewText: I have looked far and wide for an actually realistic zombie game, and just recently did I find this gem. Other games base themselves around shoot-em-up combat, but this game incorporates violence, character interaction, food, water, and medicine alike. The graphics are kind of funny at first but they kind of grow on you. I recommend turning off the music entirely because the soundtrack must've been chosen by an eight year old tripping on LSD... it ranges from techno to gentle piano to some kind of vocals to high pitched beeps. Anyway this game is probably worth $20 or more for how good it is, it's a steal at $5. I highly recommend you choose it if you crave a realistic zombie game.

reviewText:
ALMOST the ultimate zombie survival game!

You follow a hedge fund manager who took the ultimate hedge: he stocked an emergency bunker in the Mojave desert in case of a disaster.  And it paid off.

Manage multiple settlement members, press-gang thugs and looters to join you, keep your populace happy, keep everyone fed (or they'll get stupid), watch out for the undead trailing you back to your base, and looters tracking you back as well.

Social and reputation mechanics are simple but functional, though they could be a bit more transparent.  Transportation and water are your most important concerns.  Different grades of infected and infection serve different levels of danger.

The ONLY reason this game isn't THE BEST is that it lacks a bit of 'full feature' fleshing out.
I'd like to see:
more structures (kitchen/canteen, concrete barricades, mine, tents, barbed wire, stakes, irrigation...)
more types of food (particularly involving nutrition and craft cooking!  We can't eat corn forever!)
more crafting (melee weapons, fletching, clothes, duct-tape engineering)
more advancement (wooden fences have an upgrade, mines add rails, people start asking for hot showers and solar heaters)
vehicles and gasoline scavenging
house dangers (narrow sightlines and darkness make buildings more dangerous than being outside in the daytime!)
Annexing buildings (I know 'the dead can smell where we used to live', but surely they can smell where twenty people are living NOW, too!  Don't just let us, MAKE us claim certain kinds of pre-disaster buildings for benefits and requirements!)

And of course...  character creation.  I'd really like to start a sandbox style of game with all of this going on that doesn't force me to play the jackass hedge fund manager.  Don't get me wrong, I LOVE that the hedgefund manager is a jackass, not a negotiator, but the interplay between social skills, potential, and current skill level makes for some intriguing characters, not to mention the little things like lung cancer, or being a diabetic (which the game ALREADY HAS!).

reviewText:
This game is a really fanastic one. It puts you in charge of an entire community that you have to build up. You get missions to carry out for gold, you get raiders who track you from across the map, and you ge different zombies that pop up randomly. I'm just going to list the main ups and downs

Ups
-almost everyone can join your community
-Food and water are easy enough to get but hard enough to still be a task
-controls are simple and easy to learn
-each character has their own story
-each character has their opinions of other characters

Downs
-when you don't have many people, tasks can get very long and tedious
-The weight of items that each character can carry is only about 20-25 pounds
-It is difficult to get a new person into your community
-special items, such as backpacks, are very hard to find.

I reccomend this game to anyone, but it isnt and action packed shooter or hardcore survival like The Forest""
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game so far (7 hours into it at the time of writing) is extremely satisfying. a survival rpg sandbox type feel.  Graphically it is acceptable, but like many indie games, its the concept that truely sells the game.

I would like to see more added to the game (although I suspect there is plenty for now), by addition, I think a mod kit would do this game wonders for community content, stories, romances, new enemies, memes and puns, etc.  such a open and fun world to mess around in. For the price, its a steal.

Pros: Just all around a fun mixed genre game balancing out building survival, rpg, and exploration. Simple easy interface and controls. People who enjoy games like project zomboid, Dead State, and other type survival rpgs will enjoy this. Good price, could be a bit higher with more content

Cons: the graphics are not very interesting. rather bland cartoonish top down borderlands but without the charm. the chat menu can become a nuscence (would rather hit a key that open/closes chat verses autopop open and close based on proximity).  the music...the music is so out of place and terrible that I had to shut it off and just play mood music from youtube in the background..change that pronto would be my suggestion.

There is more pros and cons, and may update this down the road once I get a bit further on and truely test the limitations.


8.5/10

reviewText:
This is legitemately one of the best games I have ever bought on steam...especially for being a $5 indie game. But that said, its still not going to be  a game that everyone enjoys. The game is more focused on community building than combat, theres several structures and defensive structures you can build....although i could see the game being ALOT better with more choices in the future. Alot of people hate on the graphics, but remember its a top down indie game.....and your only paying $5 for it. The combat can be a little repetitive....and lacking in weapons (aside from fist there is only like 6 weapons i think). But like i said its more focused on building a small community and recruiting survivors to join ur community. The game can get a lil fustrating having one of the main characters being a type 1 diabetic and CONSTANTLY needing insulin which often u have to complete some fetch and kill missions to get. But your free to off her, or send her off into the wilderness alone at any time u choose, and still be able to complete the game. You loose a lil bit of the story and background....but you can still do it. The game can have some wcked replayablity since you can build anywhere....start a war with any of the other communitys or make different choices on who you want to help / kill. All in all it has plenty of flaws but way worth the $5 price tag.


-Cons:
-Somewhat repetitive combat
-The feels you get when you off one of the main characters
-Feels slightly lacking in building options and weapons
-Horrendously repetitive music
-No multiplayer currently

-Pros:
-An excellent game for anyone who enjoys city builders
-Good replayabilty, if you enjoy the game at all
-Very Resonable price tag
-Runs extremely smoothly
-Very easy to learn the game
-Complete freedom to play / build wherever and however you want
-Random attacks by hordes of zombies, and gangs of looters keeps the game from being way to overly easy
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game is deffinately worth the $5 price tag.  I have paid more for games that are much worse with less content.

The only thing that I would like to see change here is to have a low respawn rate in the areas that you have explored, or possibly some sort of zombie migration where zombies would migrate from outside the map into the cleared out areas.  I have noticed what seems to be an incidental zombie appearing once in a while in areas that I have cleared, but it is not enough to even make a slight challange.

Currently the only respawning that I have seen has been from the semi random events where zombie packs or looters detect your tracks in any town that you have explored.  This is a fairly nice feature but it is really too easy to deal with them under most situations.

Odd things:
Zombies can't break down wood walls or fences.
The green zombies are not a threat at all once you have upgraded your stats a couple of points.

My Easy Game:
I restarted my game a couple of times once I figured out how the game play worked and finally found my first sniper rifle.  First thing I did was to take my bare handed main char and hunt down the green zombies, working my way towards a location where I knew a fitness book was availible with only greens around.  By the time I went back to the totorial I had 2 stars in Fitness and 1 Fitness book which made me completely immune to greens and fairly good against blues.  I then went and grabbed both the secondary characters and grabbed the easiest sniper rifle and then finished the tutorial.

From there I would just use the Sniper rifle to explore and a shotgun to kill.  Anytime I had to take care of looters I would do head shots and one hit kill them from beyond their range.  The most problematic things so far in the game are Looters in towers which give them extra range, and white zombie hoards.

By the end of the first day I had 2-3 in both fitness and firearms for both the MC as well as the secondary Girl, while the third guy was used to act as the person who did construction.  I also pushed fitness for him as it was valuable for the few times that he went into combat as well as for increasing the carry capacity.

My current game has 9 characters with the map about half uncovered as well as all the main locations explored.  Additionally I have not once been bitten by a zombie so the antigen have not been of any value to me.  While the High end sniper ammo is not all that plentiful the shot gun and assult rifle is, not to mention about 70k of pistol ammo which is great for those you have manning towers.  This being the case the only one that carries a sniper rifle is my active character for when I am either exploring or when I am needing to take down looters.  If I could instruct my non active characters in combat behavior than I could see spreading out the sniper rifles.

reviewText:
Really worth it for $5 game, especially for Open-World game.

What I like is the surviving mechanics of course. Well there're three main aspects that you need to pay attention with to keep you alive, hunger, thirst, and sleep deprivation. There's an additional aspect for sickness. There're skills as well. You can level it up if you use its tool often. Also you can level it up by using magazine. What I liked is the skills' level will be down if you get shot but they will be recovered eventually. The combat is okay. I like the way you can aim the head, body, or legs individually based on your skill with your weapon.

I don't want to rate the story because it's not finish yet but what I dislike is the beginning of the story because it's ridiculous. Some people may notice that the girl can climb up the fence and save her sister, also why her sister brought the key? I dislike the UI, especially the font but it's pretty identical to indie game so it's quite okay. The animations for walking and sprinting are really weird.

I shocked by its musics. Totally different with the atmosphere of post-apocalyptic. But the musics make me enthusiastic.

Don't look at my gameplay stats because I played this game about 20 hours.

reviewText:
Talk about gems just popping up on the radar.

This is the kind of great idea you'd expect to see as a half-baked early access title never to truly see the light of day. But out of nowhere appears before me a complete game of the post-apocalypse where your decisions affect the game in meaningful ways.

This is just not done often enough.

The gameplay may take a little getting used to for some as it is not conventional. Personally, I was an expert after a whole of five minutes of minimal handholding.

I feel like I'm playing a game I can really sink my fangs into. An excellent buy at five; I didn't bother waiting for a sale after playing the demo (I tend to find that is another good sign, when a developer goes out of their way to publish a demo along with their title... I find even AAA titles don't even go so far). If you don't believe me, give that demo a shot. If this is your kind of game, I'm sure you will be sold in minutes, as I was.
