reviewText:
This is a phenomenal game. I bought it for $5 to kill time while I was waiting to move overseas and within three days I had 35 hours totalled up. I came close to finishing the game in that time but wasn't able to due to a difficulty in the main campaign where I had to track down a bunch of people to kill them (won't spoil it by saying precisely what).  A couple of them went missing along the way and I couldnt' find them.

Initially I thought this was a bug and contacted the dev (who responded VERY quickly and went to a lot of effort to help me).  After sending my save game the dev had a look and told me the location of a few guys still waiting around that I had to track down. I haven't played it since because I'm on a different PC with limited internet, but boy this is a fantastic game, and worth more than $5.

Buy it, you won't regret it.

reviewText: /From the moment you start playing this game, you will get drawn into it!  It's less about mind-blowing graphics and sound than it is about pure enjoyment and strategy.  The role-playing aspects and character stats are well done, and the game is remarkably free of bugs.  Gameplay is smooth, the controls easy, and building and managing a community--while seemingly overwhelming at times--is very satisfying when you do things right.\n\nThe bottom line: 9/10.  It's like a real-time Jagged Alliance 2 with zombies, and who can argue with that?  Definitely worth a lot more than the price, especially in a world where 99.9999% of modern games fail to live up to the good old days.  This one doesn't, and it's easily fun enough to play through many times over.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun! It is kind of hard though because one group member is diabetic and needs a steady supply of insulin. Encumberance is an issue as you try to decide what you should loot and what you should leave behind which makes for some really difficult choices.

Graphics: Old School, and simplistic, but they work just fine.
Controls: Pretty good.
Story: Decent.
Sound FX: Decent.
Music: Fabulous!
Group Dynamics: Yes you can play another group member or you can send them to gather or build and assign them jobs.
Open World: Yes, it is pretty big as far as I can tell, and you can do missions (mostly) in whatever order you prefer.
Crafting: Yes, a little bit, there are things to build and things you can make.
Zombies: Many seem to be fast, but I have encountered some that are slow.
Baddies: Some raiders out there need taken care of old school style.
Missions: Some are easy and some are hard. I am far from done.
Gameplay: Fun! There is plenty here to keep you very busy. Building a base will take a lot of time. There really is a lot to explore and a lot of character interaction. NPC's have wants and needs. Exploration is enjoyable wiping out cloud of war.
Advice: Get a backpack!
Money: It's worthless.
Ammo: Priceless!
Insulin: Rediculously overpriced =(

10/10 Will give the photograph to Old Man Toby again!

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game all-around. As many others have pointed out; it's definitely worth the very low price.


Pros:
Project Zomboid-esque freedom with a touch of the sims thrown in. The game is a legitimate free, open sandbox. The backstory, characters, and world are all well thought out. Controls are very straight forward, and the learning curve isn't too brutal or too casual. The progression; story, character, and gameplay!

Cons:
Single player.. which may or may not be a big deal. The insulin thing.. I won't spoil anything; but it makes it feel a lot less sandbox-y. Lack of character customization. The only thing I wish I could change about the game is that characters, traits and scenarios be a bit more random so that each playthrough could be as amazing as the first.

In conclusion:
A lot of other zombie, survival, or zombie-survival titles will not mete the itch quite as thoroughly as this one, and for less than it costs to eat at Subway... Eat flesh!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I really wanted to like this with all the loot, recruit your own survival team, and build your own base aspects...but it's too realistic as you have to manage food and water in-take, which is mostly fine, but you also have to manage sleep. I really hate games that incorporate a sleep mechanic because it forces you to take a timeout, and to top it off...the game doesn't have a fast-forward function. Yes, you can split up your team so that some of your characters sleep while you take control of others and do stuff with those who are awake, but then you will never venture out with a complete team. Having to sleep really kills the game for me. Yes, it certainly makes sense, but the creators need to realize it's a game and not some real-world simulator. A lot of potential, but not this iteration.

reviewText:
Survivalist is one of those games that you play that you can't wait for a sequel. There are a lot of great things about the game and there are some things that could have been done much better.
First the pros:
The storyline and content of the game are impressive. With a variety of win conditions that allow players to decide what type of person Joe Wheeler wants to become in the post apocalyptic nightmare that is his new life. It also has a plethora of recruitable NPC's which have their own backstories and personalities.

The combat system is straight forward and as you increase your abilities you get more ways to ensure that in a fight you're the last one standing. The fact that your characters can be infected makes fights with the horde all that more dangerous since one bite and you better start running for some anti-gen otherwise get ready to lose one of your companions and be in danger of losing even more when they finally turn.

Of course with a large cast of characters you're going to need more than just a small bunker in order to keep them all together. This leads into the construction system which is similar to combat in that the higher your level the more things you can do. Sure you can craft yourself a wooden gate but, if you want a watchtower you got to have the skills before you can actually build it.

The game gives you a small tutorial though you have to complete it in a certain time limit if you want one of the characters to stay alive. It introduces you to all of the basic skills in the game but, does allow for some trial an error (no complete hand holding but, enough of a hand to know what you're doing.)

One of the more unique takes on it has to do with the female lead. Since she's a type 1 diabetic she'll need insulin for the entire game if you want to keep her alive throguh it. This  allows for insight on exactly how difficult a post-apocalyptic world would be on those with poor health conditions. It also gives a sense of urgency to you depending on if you want to keep her alive or not.

As far as the graphics go it's not excellent but, when you take into account the game was developed by one person it's much higher quality then certain games done by teams.





For the con's there are quite a few but, mostly things that just required more work rather then actual demerits.

First the Ally AI is fairly shoddy even if those characters are profecient in weapons they don't usually use the tactical skills that they have acquired (IE: no head shots or knee capping) in command mode they will either run full speed until their fatigue bar is full or they will walk at a normal pace. Unlike a player who would mix running with letting the fatigue bar lower after a while.

Both of these can be reworked by messing with the AI however the important one (for survival sake in roming) so that a character will be told to run" until the fatigue gauge is  at a certain level before going back to a walking pace.

For consturction there is a far too little selection in the amount  of things you can build. A few different style of shaes would be nice or being able to set up automated defenses.

Next
date:
Farming. The farming system is fairly convoluted. First it takes several days before what you plant actually grows. Also it doesn't tell you when there is food ready at your camp so the farmer ends up hording it. The fact that the plants tend to blend into the ground doesn't help much either.

Raising your skills- Even though you can get a character that doesn't mean their stats are perfect. However raising the skill of a single character takes a long of time and the game doesn't really give directions on how skill gain experience (other than the obvious of "using them increases skills)

Finally the last major issue is in combat or rather "ranged combat" If you're in a fight with a set of ranged enemies it's most likely not going to end well. Even with a bulletproof vest all it will do is protect from some of the damage as you get turned into swiss cheese. Fights can be won or lost on a dime when it comes to facing human eponents

All in all I highly recommend this game in spite of it's faults because the game is very fun and gives a realistic view of what would happen if the "zombies" infested the planet. The only big problems are less about the actual game and more about the gameplay itself an how it could have done something better.


Final score 8/10"

reviewText:
Gotta say i put more time into the game, and it just isn't that fun. It's ok at first, but it needs some vast improvement before i play again.

I enjoyed the soundtrack at first, but when you roam around for long periods of time the same 3 loops over and over again start to get dull (and quite annoying).

The gunplay feels ok at best, but it mostly comes down to how much ammo you have, not how much damage a gun does or how skilled you are.

The base building is a joke, as you have to have someone that's skilled as a mechanic to even carry THE SUPPLIES for building a base back home! Why would i need to how how to use barbed wife and planks to carry the bloody things around?!?

While i enjoy the lack of voice acting, the dialogue is mediocre and the characters feel as bland and lifeless as the undead they are fighting off. The least you could do is give each character a personalty, as they aren't randomly generated and you will run into the same people time and time again.

I also feel that the game forces you along certain paths, and here's an example of what i mean: I was doing a quest for someone at one of the forts, she wanted to go see some guy she left at a police station. I liked the guy better then i liked her, as he seemed pretty polite and would make a better addition to my group. So i shot her and recruited the guy. I saved in a different slot and started my way back to my base. Half way home my people at my bunker kept getting killed. So i set the main guy on the course for home and switched back to the carpenter at my base. Turns out, the people from the fort of the woman i shot sent a death squad to my base. It may sound logical at first, but i was halfway across the damn map when i shot her! HOW ARE THEY GOING TO KNOW?!? It wasn't even a little while after either, it was right when it happened! Unless you're armed to the teeth, you are going to get annihilated. So i you even stray a little of the path the game thinks you should go on, you get severely punished.

Over all, it's a mediocre survival game with decent potential, but poor execution. I'll give this game another shot down the line to see if it is improved, but in it's current state, i strongly reccomend spending your money elsewhere.

reviewText:
Finding games like this is the reason I hang around the cheap £7 or less bargain bins, ok, mostly because I'm cheap but sometimes, every now and then you get a bargain.

I paid £3.99 for a game that gets so many things right about surviving in a zombie holocaust.

1. No special zombies, yup, no bloaters, screamers, animalistic ones, nothing that goes beyond the realm of common sense and a need to artificially make the game more challenging. There's only time you have to get an antidote before you join the population of the undead, including the white strain, which is immediate death. It means you treat every attack with the same intensity.

2. Ability to build your own safe area and the characters will carry on whilst you do other things.

3. Humanity is sick and you have to make hard decisions to get through the story line, so it should be.

I like the idea of your partner protagonists having illnesses that need attention, however if I have anything negative to say, the search for insulin is the driving force of the game, I think the game would have served better with more driving forces as it stops you from really taking in the environment whilst you're rushing about from camp to camp, doing the evil deeds of others just to get some medicine.

Honestly though, this is a fabulous game for the price and even if you don't like it, you've spent lunch on it, so it's not much of a loss.

reviewText:
Far too tedious...

- Game is ruined by the constant back and forth for 1 building supply at a time
- Constant risk of infection makes it too dangerous to bring allies with you, due to the price of antigens
- Enemy looters pretty much require you to have allies
- First character you meet has diabetes, and their meds are too pricey (I spent the first several hours trying to earn              enough gold to keep them alive, after nearly every job sent after looters I decided to bring multi npcs with me, only to have them get infected the first time I was attacked by several enemies at once and couldn't buy the antigen because I had just spent everything I had on med... Needless to say they died anyway and I no longer cared...)

- Combat became stupid once I figured out what to do, which involved:
- Infected = side step them when they come running and dive at you, or press space as soon as they tackle you, wait to get a lock on them, and aim at their legs, then  shoot them, confirm that you slowed them, if there are many, thin their numbers with headshots, then switch to your fists (to save ammo) and run up an hit them and then retreat, repeat until dead.
- Looters = have a shotgun run up in their face, as quickly as possible, and shoot them as fast as you can... they seem to out range you, and they deffinately lock on faster than you do (Sniping them might work, but as of writing this, I have found tons of sniper ammo, and been shot by snipers, but I have yet to loot one)

All this aside, it is kinda fun, but I wouldn't recomend unless you can get it really cheap.

reviewText:
The graphics are a bit simplistic but overall it's a fun game and is quite a bit more in depth than I thought it would be. The base building especially since you can set up literally anywhere on the map. Some places are easier than others due to proximity of resources but if you want to build a base off in the corner of some canyon or ontop of a hill with only one or two entry points that would be easy to defend you can.

Combat is fast, though predictable. Each fight basically comes down to trying to keep your stamina high enough to knock away Zombies that grapple you while trying to aim at legs to make them stop running or heads to just kill them quicker. One thing I don't like is there's basically no melee option, the only weapons are guns and there is a limited amount of ammo available even from traders but to be fair it's a hell of a lot, more than enough to finish the story even if you take it slow.

You can recruit as many people as you want and build your base as large as you want, your choice between sticking with a small group that's easy to manage or recruiting everyone possible and having a massive compound with farms as far as the eye can see. The advantage to the latter is you can bring a bunch of people with you and totally overwhelm any opposition. I would have liked to see an option to just join one of the other groups instead of always having to fend for yourself though.

Out of stamina and get bit? If you have the correct cure for the strain of Zombie that bit you then you're fine, if not you better hope you can find someone who has it in time or that character dies when the infection meter fills up. It adds a bit more challenge and an actual reason to be extra careful when exploring.

The other thing I really didn't like was the whole type 1 diabetes thing for one of the characters. I mean, sure, you could just forget about hunting for insulin and let her die right away and not have to deal with it but then you miss out on some very nice free skillups and some story.

All in all it's a fun game and worth the couple bucks, especially if you get it on sale.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This, in my opion, is a beautiful, yet unpolished gem of a video game, its fun, complex, and addictive (for me at least), but it also has it's share of short-comings, there is a real lack of story behind the other communities, I mean, yeah you can get the basic idea, but maybe if you could play as the other community leaders, you could have a complex action to consequence sort of story mode, say if you play as the Reed family, and you all die early on in the game, then you play as Joe later on, there could be ruins where the Reed family would've been, and so on and so on with the other communities. It could also do with some more construction options, as well as more use of insulin, there being only 1 character who uses it just makes it a pain in the butt to get it when you could just kill the character off. It also needs a changing map, the same map over and over again gets kinda boring. I know, I know, I've only been saying bad things so far, but I can't really name all of the great things about this game. Overall, this is a great game with some kinks, but has tons of potential, eventhough the game is finished besides for a patch or 2 after this time. Good job, and hope the sequel is as fun!

And it's for less than the price of one of those 'I add nothing to the game' CK2 DLCs.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game all-around. As many others have pointed out; it's definitely worth the very low price.


Pros:
Project Zomboid-esque freedom with a touch of the sims thrown in. The game is a legitimate free, open sandbox. The backstory, characters, and world are all well thought out. Controls are very straight forward, and the learning curve isn't too brutal or too casual. The progression; story, character, and gameplay!

Cons:
Single player.. which may or may not be a big deal. The insulin thing.. I won't spoil anything; but it makes it feel a lot less sandbox-y. Lack of character customization. The only thing I wish I could change about the game is that characters, traits and scenarios be a bit more random so that each playthrough could be as amazing as the first.

In conclusion:
A lot of other zombie, survival, or zombie-survival titles will not mete the itch quite as thoroughly as this one, and for less than it costs to eat at Subway... Eat flesh!

reviewText: After quite a while of searching for a decent post-apocalyptic game that didn't feature zombies (so sick of them), I finally gave in and decided to try the demo and, when it timed out, I immediately bought the full game.  While I hate the over-saturation of zombie games in the last few years, my love for post-apocalyptic-themed games infinitely out-weighs such disdain.  The inclusion of zombies did little to negatively affect my opinion.\n\nThis game is excellent in almost too many ways to name, but it does have a few faults.  Then again, what game doesn't?  I strongly recommend this game to anyone who appreciates both post-apocalyptic- and/or zombie-themed games, since it will certainly satisfy both varieties of fans.

reviewText:
PRO:
* Great value indie game - devs have done a heck of a job on a tight budget.
* Decent base building and combat in a post apocalyptic setting.
* There is a story (albeit a lean one), along with several side quests.
* Ability to control a whole community, with different members having different skills/strengths/roles - this ambitious gameplay mechanic is surprisingly well achieved in a low budget game.
* Interesting camera on third person and first person simultaneously.

CON:
* Cons are mainly to do with funding restrictions.
* Indie quality graphics and sound.
* Not much voice acting.
* AI have some issues sometimes.


Rating: 7.5/10

NOTES: Bring on Survivalist 2

reviewText: The game itself is very polished, which is rare for an indie developer now days.  I definitely appreciated that and it's worth mentioning.  I didn't come across any bugs or glitches though it did leave some things to be desired.  The AI seemed to work well for this game.  The basic concepts of survival was also fun, as were the quests.  The graphics are simple but worked for this game rather well, same with the interface.  I kept my community fairly small which I did prefer, it can quickly become a micromanaging nightmare after 10-15 members.\n\nThough the combat system was simple, I didn't like the heightened speed during combat.  Dying was so common and random during fighting with other humans" you really had to save a lot and reload if the outcome wasn't desired.  Fighting the infected was only annoying if running on fast-forward
date: since you'd easily get bitten in a second even with fast response.  Again emphasizing on saving frequently.  Also not sure about the replay value but I expect to give it a try.  It felt quite linear the first run through.  Victory conditions are kinda lame and winning was a bit of a let down as well.  There's quite a few quests
recommended: I think every person has a "job" for you to do that increases your relation with them and their community.\n\nOverall the good does outweigh the bad in this one.  Try the demo out if you're in doubt."

reviewText:
I'm not sure I can possibly speak highly enough for this game. Perhaps the fact that I've never written a review before in ten years will do that for me?

A massive world with fleshed out main characters, multiple paths to victory, simple, fast-paced combat, resource scarcity, a constant fight against the clock...honestly, for five dollars you cannot find anything better out there, in my opinion. I bought it on a whim, not even a big fan of zombie games, and I'm so impressed.

If you're reading this because you're interested, even a little, in this game, please, go through with it. I couldn't recommend it more highly.

reviewText:
I cannot believe how great this game is, and especially at this price. I'm 42 hours into it and not yet near the end. At least I don't think so. I'm the type that likes to take my time and explore slowly, finding everything. This game has a lot to explore and you can pretty much pick your own pace, at least until you run out of insulin which hasn't been a problem so far.

I found the game challenging at first, mainly because I didn't understand the dodging mechanic and I didn't realize all the options that are available to you. There are a lot of things at play here and they are not obvious at first but once you understand how things work you begin to see the simple genius behind the design. I'm only just now realizing different ways use the command interface to multitask my group far beyond simply fetching supplies.

The story is interesting and the characters have just enough individualism that I know who I like and who I send out to fetch things with low ammo and no escort :) The world feels real enough as you see NPCs in other communities relying on each other for food, bandages, water, etc.

My favorite example of NPC behavior was when I had a fist fight in a small camp of looters. After the fight, my opponent was bleeding but nobody in the camp had any bandages left. He went running off and I followed him. He made it to an abandoned car, got bandages, and stopped his bleeding. But he then ran into a zombie and got infected. He ran back to his camp asking his people for antidote but turned into a zombie before he could get help. I gained respect from the people in the camp by helping them kill him :)

I can't recommend this game enough. This is a lot of entertainment for the price of lunch.

reviewText:
Okay, so I was hunting around Steam for a relatively cheap game because I had $5 left in my wallet and wanted to make the most of it.

I sure did.

Survivalist is quite frankly the most modest/fulfilling game I have found in a long time, in all honesty it should be raised to the $7.50-$10 price range, and I shall tell you why soon.

Okay so basically TL;DR Survivalist is a post-apocalyptic zombie survival game that orientates you a year after the outbreak, all the whilst you have been barricaded inside a bunker you bought for absolutely no reason (quite coincidental if you ask me). You begin the game exactly one year on as a rich, cheesy character who emerges from his bunker looking for other signs of life, and then the adventure begins.

Before I mention about the storyline (I don't want to spoil it so I will only provide vague details) I want to talk about the general gameplay. The closest I can liken the camera angle to is Diablo, fixated roughly birds-eye but angled slightly towards the player. This allows for a good view of the surrounding area, but doesn't impede imersion at all. Your character also follows the direction of your mouse, which is a good quality as you are easily able to pick off zombies as they come screaming towards you. The aiming aspect of the game I believe is unique, yet brilliant; your accuracy is basically zero if you are 'run and gunning' so to be able to kill zombies you need to stay still, juke side to side while plinking them off. The sound is also relatively ambient, however after a fair amount of time the footstep sound can get a little repetitive, but don't get me wrong it definitely adds to the realism of the game. Occasionally you hear the words Eeeviillll" coming from a zombie somewhere in the close vicinity
date: but I love this cheesiness considering the game only costs $5
recommended: and I have absolutely no problem with it. Although the only aspect of the sound that I consider irritating is when you over-encumber/fatigue; the heavy breathing your character embodies (despite realism) is loud and kind of annoying but oh well
hoursPlayed: thats a minute flaw in a brilliant game.\n\nNow basically this game grasps every concept of a fantastic zombie survival on a minimalistic
voteText: but perfect scale. You cannot carry over a certain weight in items
helpfulPercent: but this can be enlargened through increasing your fitness skill (by running) or by obtaining different backpacks. You have a constant need to find water and food but on top of that ammo is relatively scarce so you need to make use of it considering zombies take a fair amount to bring down. You can also band up with other survivors to create a community
votesHelpful: each with different assets like construction/medicine that can help improve your chances to survive. That brings me to the point of base-creation
votesTotal: which in this game is just amazing; you have to collect building resources such as wood and concrete to be able to fence off an area and construct buildings/defenses for a good defense agaisnt the undead. I love this aspect of the game
votesFunny: I didn't expect it to be there at all considering the price but oh boy does it make the difference. However early on you are established as the alpha of the group
commentsCount: and that means catering to the Type-1 Diabetic who requires Insulin constantly
column16: which in this world doesn't come cheap at all.\n\nThe one thing that really impresses me though is this game is made by a single guy. Just one developer
column17: who hasn't given up on the game (online co-op is in beta now with constant updates) which brings happiness to my heart considering most developers these days give up on early-access. For this guy to be able to create such a simplistic
column18: perfect zombie survival is beyond me
column19: and that is why I believe the price should be raised.\n\nI definitely recommend this game 100%
column20: and at this point I only have 3.5 hours but I feel like that number will just skyrocket."

reviewText:
This is one of those games that it's hard to recomend, but I still feel like it just deserves to be so since, all things told, I did actually enjoy it despite it's flaws and bugs.

There are some bad things about this game: the AI is dumb as hell, the missions all get very same-y very quick, resource management is a pain in the butt, and since how much an NPC likes or hates you varies by character to character rather than your group as a whole, it's sometimes hard to remember which one of your characters you need to have talk to which NPC to get them to do something or give you something.

This game also has a lot of down time; points where so many of my characters were wounded or I needed so many supplies that were far away, that I just sent my NPCs off to heal/gather while I walked away from my computer. This didn't just happen a few times, but A LOT.

HOWEVER! Once you get ahold of how the game works/plays it becomes chanllenging enough without being too hard or too easy. I enjoyed the freedom of the basebuilding and felt a real sense of victory when I had my entire bunker surrounded by a dual layer of fences and a careful spreading of guard towers and pillboxes.

And I had a ton of fun becoming the new superpower of the wasteland by growing my settlement one person at a time. Those who could not be persuaded, bought, or threatened into joining me were met with a swift end. It's the end of the world, baby, and you're either with me, or you're dead.

In the end, Survivalist is a game worth picking up if you're a major zombie fan, are in the mood for something new, and it's on sale. For less than five bucks, you're actually getting a fairly good (albeit wonky) game.

reviewText:
PRO:
* Great value indie game - devs have done a heck of a job on a tight budget.
* Decent base building and combat in a post apocalyptic setting.
* There is a story (albeit a lean one), along with several side quests.
* Ability to control a whole community, with different members having different skills/strengths/roles - this ambitious gameplay mechanic is surprisingly well achieved in a low budget game.
* Interesting camera on third person and first person simultaneously.

CON:
* Cons are mainly to do with funding restrictions.
* Indie quality graphics and sound.
* Not much voice acting.
* AI have some issues sometimes.


Rating: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Great game, amazing deal for the price you're paying.

Pros
-Decent story (I personally did the love ending and I found the story to be great but that may differ on which win condition you choose
-Fairly challenging game
-Lots of surprises which makes the gameplay a lot more exciting, you must expect the unexpected
-Controls are a bit awkward at first, but as you get used to them it becomes fairly smooth and convienient
-It contains elements of townbuilding, which would be a plus or minus depending on what you like (I personally liked this aspect of the game)

Cons
-Moving from one side to another is quite the pain since you have to have your character run the whole thing and running consumes stamina and low stamina makes you vulnerable to zombie bites so it can take quite a bit of time just getting to one place to another
-The lack of a group auto function for example, have 4 survivalists farming and managing them as a group so you dont have to go to each one and tell them to farm
-Sniper rifle is pretty broken, it lets you deal with a huge number of looters without much risk (I guess this isnt really a big issue since sniper rifle ammo is quite rare, but even so)

Overall, I would highly recommend this game. Lots of fun, defintely one of the more enjoyable indie games Ive played.

reviewText: While there are things I liked about this game, the bottom line is that the combat is atrocious.   I liked some of the other systems and there's an actual story to the game that I would have liked to have seen through but unfortunately there's a lot of combat and it's just frustratingly designed.\nI got this on a steam sale, so I only paid about $3.00 U.S.  so I don't feel like I was ripped off, but every time I have to fight anything with ranged weapons or engage in a fist fight with the 300+ survivors that want to fistfight I'm just left bewildered that anyone thought this combat system was acceptable.   People compare this to State of Decay, but having played both, despite some problems, State of Decay seems like a polished triple A title compared to this game.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Had no idea such a simple game on the surface could be so darn addicting in execution. Think State of Decay meets Project Zomboid mixed with 28 Days later zeds  and you got the gist. Building up a community is fun and engaging. Even the..ahem...complications with one of the starting chracters I found made the game more compelling when it could easily have been bloody irritating. So kudos devs for taking a creative chance there.
What really makes this game for me however is command mode. Basically, you can go into a Sims style overworld view to tell chracters your not directly controlling what to do. Gather resources, build, or whatever. And the best part is you don't have to micro-manage every little thing! They need food or water? They find it! They need more materials for that build? They head to the nearest cache and grab materials. And mostly they intelligently defend themselves (wouldn't suggest letting them auto into looters though. That never seems to end well).
All in all, a fantastic game especailly given the price. And the recently added multi-player serves only to give it more replayability. I would highly suggest this one to anyone more interested in community interactions with their zombie survival instead of just scavaging and waiting to die.
Oh, and last note. The combat I find to be extremely engrossing. The fast paced zeds and erratic nature of shoot-outs with looters will keep you entertained!

Building up a community is fun and engaging. Even the..ahem...complications with one of the starting chracters I found made the game more compelling when it could easily have been bloody irritating. What really makes this game for me however is command mode. Basically, you can go into a Sims style overworld view to tell chracters your not directly controlling what to do. Gather resources, build, or whatever. And the best part is you don't have to micro-manage every little thing! They need food or water? They find it! They need more materials for that build? They head to the nearest cache and grab materials. And mostly they intelligently defend themselves (wouldn't suggest letting them auto into looters though. That never seems to end well).
All in all, a fantastic game especailly given the price. And the recently added multi-player serves only to give it more replayability. I would highly suggest this one to anyone more interested in community interactions with their zombie survival instead of just scavaging and waiting to die.
Oh, and last note. The combat I find to be extremely engrossing. The fast paced zeds and erratic nature of shoot-outs with looters will keep you entertained!

reviewText: This is one of those good ole very hard to start but once you get started gets easier kind of rpgs. Survivalist is a top-down shoopter with rpg elements. As I first stated in the begining dont expect to run to your nearast town and rambo your way through. It wont happen. This is a in depth (in my opinion which may be crap to your) real survival game. No your not Bear Gryilles (or what ever that crap his last name is) eating poop and drinking pee. But you do have to manage food, water, sleep, etc. Also on top of that you have to manage Alice's type 1 diebetes. YAY, which means your'll constantly be running around looking for food and water and insulin. As I said this isn't easy starting off. As all games should be,  in the beggining your gonna be moslty scaveging for food and water and ammo and insulin. Then you'll head back to the bunker to start making your camp. Here's where it starts getting intense. Now your'll have to juggle using only one survivor Joe. For the time being. So that means you'll have to split food,water,ammo,and else. But enough rambling. Once you finally start builgind a comminuty the real action starts. I found myself constantly getting attacked while i was building or away. SO now your gonna have to start getting wood, and metal to secure your small comunity. As you start to accumulate more and more in your community your begin to realize hey I dont have to scavenge as often i have farms and wells. While ammo and insulin and building supplies now on the top of the GOT GET IT ALL list. Soon your'll feel safer leaving your comminuty alone from time to time knowing hey anything comes close ole buckeye pete and his m16 will gun it down. Of corse nothing is invincble but you'll feel better knowing raiders cant burn down chain-link fences. Soon the game gets easy for the time till it catches up with harder zombies. Now with that talk of coop it makes tingle inside knowing I can be guarding my community while someone else scavages. So I rate this a 9/10 IGN very very fun but gets kinda repetitive. Very hard early one. But hard fun.? (sounded better in my head). I would reccomend you get this. But learn to come and love the restart button

reviewText: Survivalist is a surprising find. I don't know how to describe it to anyone that the other comments don't already do a good job of doing. You play as a survivor, you find other people along the way exploring, you do missions for other groups, build up your resources, including building your own town. It is beautiful in its simplicity and wonderful in a sandbox survival with a light hearted story. The fact is I wish there were more buildings, or atleast options to choose colors for your buildings. The game has a lot of amazing fun moments, and some over the top ridiculous story arcs, which made me laugh and I enjoyed the time I've played. If you want a game that will keep you surviving, wheeling and dealing, searching and constantly strategizing on how to get the upper hand, this game is a must play.
